# Quick, Easy, and Delicious: The Appeal of Vietnamese Instant Coffee
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
8 min
[](https://vivavn.com/coffee/)
Coffee
[](https://youtube.com/shorts/PjQGERbWluE)
_Vietnamese instant coffee is a convenient way to enjoy a rich and creamy cup of coffee that smells amazing and tastes delicious. With its smooth texture and yummy flavor, this instant coffee captures the essence of Vietnam’s coffee culture in just moments._
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial "YouTube")
[](https://www.facebook.com/vivavnofficial2024 "Facebook")
[](https://www.pinterest.com/vivavnofficial/ "Pinterest")
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
### [Vietnamese Coconut Nectar: Sokfarm’s Sustainable Sweetener](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
## Introduction
**[Vietnamese coffee](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coffee/)** is beloved worldwide, not just for its traditional phin-brewed variety but also for its instant coffee. This article will delve into the origins of coffee in Vietnam and the emergence of instant coffee in this coffee-loving nation.
We’ll highlight what makes Vietnamese instant coffee unique, from its creation process to the distinctive smooth and creamy flavor it offers. You’ll also discover popular brands, the benefits of Vietnamese instant coffee, and where to buy it. Whether you’re a coffee enthusiast or simply curious, this guide will provide you with everything you need to appreciate and enjoy Vietnamese instant coffee.
## History of Vietnamese Instant Coffee
In the 19th century, the French brought coffee and [**the phin filter**](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coffee-filters/) to Vietnam. The phin has since become an iconic part of Vietnamese coffee culture. Its slow extraction process results in a uniquely rich and aromatic coffee, but this method requires time, making it less convenient for those with busy lifestyles.
The birth of Vietnamese instant coffee can be traced back to the establishment of the Vinacafe factory in 1969. This convenient alternative to traditional phin coffee quickly became popular. Instant coffee, which only requires hot water, offers a quicker and simpler way to enjoy coffee compared to the time-consuming phin method. Exported internationally, it’s loved for its rich, flavorful taste. Today, Vietnamese instant coffee remains a favorite for its convenience and delightful aroma.
## The Advantages of Vietnamese Instant Coffee
**Convenience** : One of the most significant advantages of Vietnamese Instant Coffee is its unparalleled convenience. Whether you’re on the go, at the office, or simply seeking a quick caffeine fix, this instant coffee offers a hassle-free solution. With just a few simple steps, you can enjoy a rich and flavorful cup of coffee anytime, anywhere.
**Authentic Flavor** : Despite its convenience, Vietnamese Instant Coffee does not compromise on flavor. The meticulous roasting and blending process ensures that the authentic taste of Vietnamese coffee is preserved, allowing you to savor the rich, bold, and slightly sweet notes that have made this brew so beloved.
**Affordability** : Vietnamese Instant Coffee is a budget-friendly option that doesn’t sacrifice quality. Its affordability makes it accessible to coffee lovers from all walks of life, ensuring that everyone can indulge in the unique flavors of this exceptional brew without breaking the bank.
## What makes Vietnamese Instant Coffee Unique?
Vietnamese instant coffee stands out for its distinctive flavor profile, which differs markedly from typical instant coffees. Unlike the often burnt and overly sweet taste of many instant brands, Vietnamese instant coffee offers a unique flavor with a harmonious balance of ingredients. This unique profile is largely due to the use of robusta coffee beans, which thrive in Vietnam’s ideal climate and soil conditions. Robusta beans contribute to the coffee’s rich, full-bodied flavor and robust characteristics.
The balance of these flavors ensures that the coffee is not overly sweet. Its well-balanced creaminess provides a smooth, satisfying taste without being overwhelming. Each cup delivers a delightful and well-rounded coffee experience, reflecting the exceptional growing conditions and the cultural emphasis on quality and flavor in Vietnamese coffee.
## Popular Vietnamese Instant Coffee Brands
The market is brimming with a variety of Vietnamese Instant Coffee brands, each offering its unique take on this beloved beverage. Some of the best Vietnamese instant coffee options such as:
### Trung Nguyen
Trung Nguyen has been pivotal in bringing Vietnamese coffee to the global stage since 1996. Renowned for its Vietnamese drip coffee and premium products, Trung Nguyen also offers high-quality instant coffee. With its unique flavors now enjoyed in over 60 countries, Trung Nguyen stands as a true icon of Vietnamese coffee culture.
Trung Nguyên’s G7 instant coffee line offers a taste of Vietnam’s best coffee. The G7 3-in-1 combines coffee, cream, and sugar from Buon Ma Thuot’s legendary soil. G7 Pure Black is bold and pure, perfect for those who like to customize their coffee. The G7 Espresso, made from Arabica beans, delivers a strong yet gentle flavor. Lastly, G7 Cappuccino offers a delightful Italian-style coffee with thick, soft milk foam and flavors of coconut or hazelnut.
### Vinacafe
Vinacafe, Vietnam’s first instant coffee brand, has been a beloved choice since its inception in 1969. Famous for its 3-in-1 instant coffee, Vinacafe delivers a smooth taste that’s not overly sweet, perfect for those who enjoy a balanced flavor. This coffee not only tastes great but also gives you that much-needed energy boost to kickstart your mornings.
### King Coffee
King Coffee, launched in 2016 by Le Hoang Diep Thao, who has over 25 years of experience in the coffee industry, truly understands the coffee of Vietnam’s Central Highlands. The brand is known for its beautiful, elegant packaging and offers instant coffee made from robusta beans. King Coffee boasts a rich, aromatic flavor that coffee lovers will appreciate.
## How to Prepare Vietnamese Instant Coffee
Preparing Vietnamese Instant Coffee is a breeze, making it an ideal choice for those on the go or with limited time. Here’s a simple step-by-step guide:
**Gather your ingredients:** Vietnamese instant coffee generally comes in two types. The first type is pre-mixed with sugar, milk, and cream, so you don’t need to add anything extra—just mix with hot water. The second type is 100% coffee, where you can add your own sweeteners, milk, or cream according to your taste preferences.
**Mix the coffee:** In a mug or glass, combine the desired amount of Vietnamese Instant Coffee powder with a small amount of hot (or cold) water. Stir until the powder is fully dissolved, creating a concentrated coffee mixture.
**Add your extras:** If you prefer your coffee sweetened or with milk/creamer, now is the time to incorporate those ingredients. Adjust the amounts to your taste preferences.
**Top it off:** Finally, fill your mug or glass with the remaining hot (or cold) water, giving it a gentle stir to ensure everything is well combined.
**Enjoy:** Sit back, relax, and savor the rich, aromatic flavors of your freshly prepared Vietnamese Instant Coffee.
## Where to Buy Vietnamese Instant Coffee
Here are some options for purchasing Vietnamese Instant Coffee:
**Vietnamese markets:** If you have access to a Vietnamese market or community, these stores are likely to have an extensive selection of authentic Vietnamese Instant Coffee brands.
**Online retailers:** Major online retailers like Amazon, eBay, and various specialty coffee websites offer a wide range of Vietnamese Instant Coffee options, often with convenient shipping options.

# Vietnamese Lotus Tea: A Unique and Captivating Beverage
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
4 min
[](https://vivavn.com/tea/)
Tea
_In Vietnam, lotus tea symbolizes the essence of[ Vietnamese tea ](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-tea/)culture. This unique tea boasts a captivating flavor and is crafted through a meticulous process that’s almost like an art form!_
## When did Vietnamese lotus tea originate?
Up to now, there isn’t any document that accurately states when Vietnamese lotus tea originated. However, according to Vietnamese folklore, lotus tea has been around for a long time. It’s said that during the Nguyen dynasty in Hue, the kings often ordered servants to row boats to lotus ponds to select the most fragrant lotus blossoms for making lotus tea.
During the summer months, during the time of the Nguyen Dynasty emperors. Highly skilled servants would row out to the middle of the lotus pond at night and find the perfect buds. They would carefully place the tea leaves inside each flower and tie them shut with thin [bamboo ](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-bamboo/)strips.
The next morning, the servants would return to the pond and collect the tea. They would then use the dew that had gathered on the lotus leaves to boil water and brew the tea. This special process infused the tea with the delicate and unique fragrance of the lotus flower, creating a truly delightful cup of tea.
## There are two main ways Vietnamese people make lotus tea today
To make delicious lotus tea, Vietnamese people believe that the lotus flowers must be harvested in the early morning, just as they are beginning to bloom. This is the time when the flowers are most fragrant.
The harvesting process must be done very carefully to avoid damaging the delicate petals. After harvesting the lotus flowers, Vietnamese people have two ways to make lotus tea:
### The first way
**1. Nesting the Tea Leaves:** The process begins with carefully tucking tea leaves inside the unopened lotus buds.
**2**. **Protective Wrap:** To further protect the delicate contents, the entire bud is then wrapped in a layer of fresh lotus leaves.
**3. Securing the Bud:** Once the bud is wrapped in lotus leaves, a thin bamboo strip is used to tie it shut.
**4. Overnight Infusion:** The final step is to leave the wrapped lotus bud to rest overnight. During this time, the tea leaves gently absorb the wonderful essence of the lotus flower. The fragrance and flavors slowly transfer from the flower to the tea leaves, creating the unique taste of lotus tea.
### The second way
This is a meticulous method of making lotus tea, but the resulting flavor will be exquisite and can be enjoyed throughout the year.
**1. Separating Stamens:** This step focuses on carefully harvesting the fragrant part of the lotus flower.
– The tea maker starts by gently opening the unopened lotus buds.
– They then meticulously **extract** the stamens, which are the male reproductive organs of the flower.
– Importantly, they only select the **white portion** of the stamen, which is likely the most flavorful part.
**2. Infusing the Tea:** This step focuses on transferring the lotus flower’s essence to the tea leaves.
– The extracted white stamen is placed directly into green tea leaves.
– This mixture is left for **several days** , allowing the flavors to **meld together**.
– During this infusion process, the delicate aroma and taste of the lotus flower are absorbed by the green tea leaves.
**3. Separating the green tea leaves from the stamen:** This step ensures the final tea doesn’t contain unwanted elements.
– The tea maker uses a **traditional tool** to separate the green tea leaves from the used stamen.
– This ensures that only the green tea leaves, now infused with the lotus flavor, remain for brewing.
## Famous places for delicious lotus tea in Vietnam
### Hanoi
The lotus tea of Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam, is considered to be one of the finest in this country. This is due in part to the unique qualities of the lotus flowers grown in West Lake ( Vietnamese: Hồ Tây), which is located northwest of the city center. The lotus flowers grown in West Lake are known for their intense fragrance.
### Hue
Hue, Vietnam’s former imperial capital, boasts a reputation for exquisite lotus tea. This prized beverage was a popular choice during the [Nguyen Dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty), enjoyed by the royal court. To ensure its perfection, only the finest lotus flowers were handpicked and meticulously prepared by the most skilled artisans.
Today, the people of Hue continue to preserve this ancient tradition, crafting lotus tea with the same dedication and care. The result is a truly exceptional tea that embodies the rich history and cultural heritage of Vietnam.

# The Ultimate Guide to Vietnamese Coffee: History & Recipes
In this article, we’re excited to share with you some fascinating insights into Vietnamese coffee.
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
10 min
[](https://vivavn.com/coffee/)
Coffee
[](https://youtube.com/shorts/PjQGERbWluE)
_Vietnamese coffee, with its unique preparation methods and distinctive flavors, has captured the hearts of coffee enthusiasts worldwide. Known for its robust intensity and diverse variations, Vietnamese coffee uses locally sourced Vietnamese coffee beans that contribute to its rich and bold profile._
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial "YouTube")
[](https://www.facebook.com/vivavnofficial2024 "Facebook")
[](https://www.pinterest.com/vivavnofficial/ "Pinterest")
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
### [Vietnamese Coconut Nectar: Sokfarm’s Sustainable Sweetener](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
This comprehensive article will cover the history of Vietnamese coffee, highlighting its evolution and the role it plays in Vietnam’s culture.
It will take readers through a journey exploring popular Vietnamese coffee varieties, such as the iconic Vietnamese iced coffee, Vietnamese coffee with egg, and Vietnamese salt coffee.
Additionally, it will discuss the reasons behind its robust and intense flavor profile, health benefits and considerations, and cultural significance.
For those curious about the brewing process, it will provide a step-by-step guide on how to use a [**Vietnamese coffee filter**](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coffee-filters/), leading to the perfect cup of Vietnamese black coffee. The article will also include recommendations for the best Vietnamese coffee brands and cafés and suggest ways to pair and serve these delightful beverages.
Through these sections, readers will gain a deeper appreciation and understanding of Vietnamese coffee, enabling them to explore its rich flavors and textures in their own homes.
## History and origins of Vietnamese coffee
Coffee was first introduced to Vietnam by the French in 1857, which they brought from **[Martinique](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martinique)** and [**French Guiana**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Guiana) in Latin America due to the similar tropical climate and soil conditions.
Initially, they experimented with growing Arabica coffee in the **[northern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Vietnam)** and **[central](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Vietnam)** regions of Vietnam. The harvested beans were then processed and sold under the brand Arabica du Tonkin and imported back to France.
In 1925, after conducting extensive surveys of Vietnam’s climate and soil, the French decided to try growing coffee in the [**Central Highlands**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Highlands_\(Vietnam\)). They found that the **[Lang Biang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_L%E1%BA%A1t_Plateau)** Plateau was ideal for Arabica, while regions like **[Dak Lak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%AFk_L%E1%BA%AFk_province)** were better suited for Robusta.
Today, Vietnam is the **[second-largest](https://vietnam.vn/en/kim-ngach-xuat-khau-ca-phe-cua-viet-nam-nam-2023-cao-ky-luc-dat-424-ty-usd/)** coffee exporter in the world, even though it ranks sixth globally in terms of coffee-growing area.
Arabica and Robusta coffee differ in caffeine content and growing conditions. Arabica has 1.12 – 1.7% caffeine and grows best at 59 – 77°F (15 – 25°C) in high altitudes of 900 – 2000 meters. Robusta, with 2 – 2.7% caffeine, thrives in warmer temperatures of 68 – 86°F (20 – 30°C) at lower altitudes of 0 – 900 meters.
## Vietnam’s renowned coffee-growing regions
### Central Highlands
The Central Highlands of Vietnam are perfect for coffee cultivation. With a tropical, humid climate, an elevation of around 500-600 meters, and over 2 million hectares of rich basalt soil, this region is ideal for growing robusta coffee, contributing to 95% of Vietnam’s coffee production. Additionally, certain areas in **[Lam Dong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%C3%A2m_%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng_province)** province, located at elevations above 1500 meters with cooler climates, are perfect for cultivating high-quality Arabica coffee.
### Khe Sanh
In central Vietnam, there’s a place called [**Khe Sanh**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khe_Sanh#:~:text=Khe%20Sanh%20is%20the%20district,km%20west%20of%20%C4%90%C3%B4ng%20H%C3%A0.&text=During%20the%20Vietnam%20War%2C%20the,of%20the%20war%20are%20exhibited.) in **[Quang Tri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Tr%E1%BB%8B_province)** province. This region is characterized by its hilly terrain, fertile soil, and cool climate year-round, making it perfect for coffee cultivation. The French introduced coffee here in the early 20th century. Interestingly, Arabica coffee in Khe Sanh is grown at an elevation of just 600 meters above sea level, yet it boasts a unique flavor.
### Northwest (Vietnam)
The **[Northwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_\(Vietnam\))** region of Vietnam, mainly the provinces of **[Son La](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C6%A1n_La_province)** and **[Dien Bien](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_province)** , offers the perfect soil and climate for growing Arabica coffee. This area is characterized by its impressive mountain ranges, with Arabica coffee thriving at elevations between 900 and 1200 meters. The Arabica plants here grow very well, producing high-quality beans. Son La is the second largest Arabica coffee-growing province in Vietnam, right after Lam Dong.
## Popular Vietnamese coffee varieties
### Ca phe sua da (Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk)
**[Vietnamese iced coffee](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-iced-coffee/)** , or ca phe sua da, is a tasty drink with a strong flavor and a smooth, slightly sweet taste from the condensed milk. It’s made using a small metal drip filter called a “phin.” To make it, Vietnamese people put the coffee grounds in the phin, pour hot water over them, and let the coffee drip slowly into a glass below.
Once the coffee has finished dripping, they use a spoon to stir and mix the coffee with the condensed milk thoroughly. This method makes a strong, aromatic coffee that mixes well with the sweetness of the condensed milk, making it a great treat, especially on a hot day.
### Ca phe den (black coffee)
The way to make this coffee is like making Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk, but without the milk. Instead, a little sugar is added. This lets people enjoy the pure, strong flavor of the coffee. Without the milk, the true taste of the coffee stands out, making it perfect for those who love a rich coffee flavor.
### Ca phe muoi (salted coffee)
Salted coffee has emerged as a beloved trend in Vietnam in recent years. This unique beverage combines condensed milk, coffee, and a touch of salted cream. The flavor profile is a perfect blend of sweetness from the milk, the bitterness of coffee, and a subtle salty undertone. It’s a refreshing and satisfying drink that offers a harmonious balance of flavors.
### Ca phe trung (egg coffee)
Egg coffee is a unique beverage originating from the capital city of Hanoi, Vietnam. It includes fresh egg yolks, sugar, condensed milk, and coffee. To make egg coffee, Vietnamese people whip the egg yolks with condensed milk and sugar until they form a thick, creamy foam. This mixture is then poured over brewed coffee made using a phin filter.
Egg coffee originated in Hanoi, Vietnam in the 1940s, created by Mr. Nguyen Van Giang. While working as a bartender at a hotel, he came up with the idea of using eggs to make coffee due to a shortage of milk.
### Bac Xiu
Bac Xiu, which translates to “white coffee,” is a lighter and creamier variation of the traditional Vietnamese iced coffee. It contains a higher ratio of milk to coffee, using fresh and condensed milk, giving it a smoother and more delicate flavor profile. This coffee variant is especially popular for its gentle coffee aroma.
## Unique characteristics of Vietnamese coffee
Vietnamese coffee is renowned for its robust and intense flavor profile. This distinctive taste is attributed to several factors.
### **Robusta beans**
Vietnam is the second-largest coffee exporter in the world, primarily growing robusta beans, while arabica is more popular globally. Robusta beans have a higher caffeine content (2 – 2.7%) than arabica (1.12 – 1.7%), resulting in a more bitter taste (the higher caffeine content contributes to the increased bitterness). Additionally, robusta beans contain 60% less fats and sugars than arabica beans, further influencing their flavor profile.
### Over-roasting
Local Vietnamese coffee producers often over-roast the beans, which adds to Vietnamese coffee’s distinctive flavor and aroma.
### Traditional Vietnamese Phin filter
Additionally, the traditional Vietnamese phin filter is used for brewing. This method takes longer, allowing more of the coffee’s active compounds to be extracted, resulting in a stronger, more robust cup.
## Health benefits of coffee
### Energizing benefits
Coffee is more than just a morning drink; it’s a great way to wake up and feel energized. The secret ingredient is **[caffeine](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30137774/)** , which stimulates the brain and nervous system. Caffeine works by blocking [**adenosine**](https://nutritionsource.hsph.harvard.edu/caffeine/), a chemical that makes you feel sleepy and relaxed. When adenosine is blocked, you stay alert and less tired.
### Coffee consumption may lower type 2 diabetes risk
Diabetes is a widespread global health concern, with predictions indicating that by 2030, 552 million people worldwide will be affected by this condition. However, there is promising evidence suggesting that coffee consumption may help reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes. Studies have shown a link between moderate coffee intake and lower disease incidence. For more detailed information on these studies, you can find them [[**here**](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6003581/)]
### Enhance heart health
Studies indicate that regularly consuming coffee, especially **[3-5 cups](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29276945/)** per day, is associated with a 15% lower risk of cardiovascular disease and lower mortality rates among healthy individuals.
### Support brain health
Regular intake of coffee has been associated with a lower risk of neurodegenerative diseases such as [**Parkinson’s**](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7353179/) and **[Alzheimer’s](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26944757/)**. Studies suggest that caffeine can lower the risk of developing dementia and cognitive decline.
## Cultural significance
In Vietnam, coffee is more than just a drink; it’s a lifestyle deeply rooted in the culture. Introduced by French missionaries in the 19th century, coffee quickly became a local favorite. It evolved from its colonial roots to symbolize Vietnamese creativity and identity. Today, Vietnam is the world’s second-largest coffee exporter, mainly producing robusta beans. These beans are known for their strong flavor, often sweetened with condensed milk to balance their natural bitterness.
Vietnamese coffee culture is known for its unique preparation and consumption practices. The traditional phin filter, a single-cup drip method, highlights this uniqueness and promotes a leisurely pace of life. Locals often enjoy their coffee slowly, reflecting the societal value placed on savoring moments. This is a stark contrast to the fast-paced coffee culture of the West.
The social aspect of coffee in Vietnam is equally significant. Coffee shops and street stalls are not just places to drink coffee; they are venues where people gather to catch up on news and enjoy each other’s company at any time of the day. This communal aspect is a cornerstone of Vietnamese daily life, making coffee shops central to social interactions in both urban and rural areas.
Moreover, places like Cafe Giang have survived changes in location and succeeded by keeping their traditional recipes that both locals and tourists love. The cafe’s famous egg coffee, made with robusta coffee, condensed milk, and egg yolk, shows the creative spirit of Vietnam’s coffee culture.
## Popular brands and cafés
### The best Vietnamese coffee brands
**[Trung Nguyen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trung_Nguy%C3%AAn)** has played a pivotal role in popularizing Vietnamese coffee both domestically and internationally since its inception in 1996. Known for its Vietnamese drip coffee, high-quality [**instant coffee**](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-instant-coffee/), and a variety of premium coffee products, Trung Nguyen has successfully exported its unique flavors to [**over 60 countries**](https://trungnguyenlegend.com/milestones/?lang=en), making it a cornerstone of Vietnamese coffee culture.
**[Vinacafe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vinacafe)** stands out for its commitment to high-quality coffee, focusing on traditional roasting methods and locally sourced beans. This brand is particularly noted for its instant coffee products, which have contributed significantly to Vietnam’s coffee exports.
King Coffee, founded by [**Le Hoang Diep Thao**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le_Hoang_Diep_Thao), has expanded its presence beyond Vietnam, offering a range of coffee products that cater to global tastes while maintaining a focus on quality and innovation. This brand’s growth reflects its ambition to share Vietnamese coffee culture worldwide.
### Famous coffee shops in Vietnam
#### Trung Nguyen Legend
As of 2024, Trung Nguyen Legend boasts nearly 1,000 locations in Vietnam and is making significant strides globally. In July 2024, the brand expanded by opening 10 new stores in the United States and China. The Trung Nguyen Legend cafes in the U.S. offer a unique experience, featuring drip coffee and espresso made from 100% robusta and arabica beans grown in Vietnam. Additionally, their Zen Coffee, a distinctive creation by Trung Nguyen Legend, has been praised for providing a fresh and unique coffee experience that many find truly transformative.
#### Highlands Coffee
Highlands Coffee, with over 600 locations, stands out as a major player in the Vietnamese coffee market, known for its affordable yet quality offerings. The chain provides a cozy atmosphere combining modern and traditional elements, making it a popular choice among locals and tourists alike.
#### Cong Caphe
Cong Caphe, also known as Cong Coffee, is celebrated for its vintage décor and commitment to preserving Vietnam’s cultural heritage. The coffeehouse chain offers traditional Vietnamese coffee and a variety of snacks and desserts, enhancing the overall coffee experience.
#### Phuc Long Coffee & Tea House
Phuc Long Coffee & Tea House, since its inception in 1968, has grown to become a beloved brand for its high-quality Vietnamese tea and coffee. The brand’s commitment to traditional brewing methods and locally sourced ingredients contributes to its authentic beverages.
## How to brew Vietnamese coffee at home
To brew authentic Vietnamese coffee at home, one must gather the necessary equipment and ingredients, which include a Vietnamese Phin filter, ground coffee beans, and optionally, sweetened condensed milk. The Phin filter, a crucial tool, consists of three parts: the body, the press or filter disk, and the lid, designed to facilitate a slow drip that enhances the coffee’s flavor.
### Step-by-step brewing process
  * **Prepare the equipment** : Start by assembling your Phin filter and a heatproof glass or mug. If using sweetened condensed milk, spoon the desired amount into the cup before beginning the brewing process.


  * **Boil water** : Heat water to a temperature between 195°-205°F. This specific range is crucial as it is ideal for extracting the full flavor from the coffee without scalding it.


  * **Preheat the phin and cup** : Pour a small amount of the boiled water through the Phin to preheat the filter and the cup. This step ensures the coffee brews at a consistent temperature.


  * **Add coffee grounds** : Place one heaping tablespoon of fine Vietnamese coffee grounds into the Phin. Use the filter press to lightly tamp down the grounds, preparing them for brewing.


  * **Brew the coffee** : Continue to pour hot water into the Phin until it reaches the top. Cover with the lid and allow the coffee to drip slowly through the filter. This process should take about [3-5 minutes](https://iamafoodblog.com/vietnamese-coffee/), resulting in a rich and concentrated brew.


  * **Final touches** : Once the brewing is complete, remove the Phin and stir the coffee. For a traditional iced version, pour the brew over ice, or add more hot water for a milder drink.


### Tips for optimal flavor
  * **Do Not Over-Compress the Coffee** : When adding coffee to the filter, avoid shaking or compressing it excessively. This can clog the filter and hinder the drip process, affecting the overall flavor and brewing time.


  * **Adjust Condensed Milk to Taste** : The amount of sweetened condensed milk can vary depending on personal preference, ranging from one tablespoon for regular coffee to three tablespoons for a very sweet taste.


By following these steps and tips, one can enjoy a delightful cup of Vietnamese coffee, rich in flavor and tradition, right at home.
## Traditional Vietnamese breakfasts and coffee pairings
In Vietnam, it’s common to start the morning with a breakfast that includes dishes like Pho and Banh Mi. After enjoying these flavorful and satisfying meals, many Vietnamese people then indulge in a cup of robust Vietnamese coffee.
This routine highlights the cultural significance of balancing the rich flavors of a traditional breakfast with the strong, aromatic notes of Vietnamese coffee, making for a complete and enjoyable morning experience.

# **The Most Cultivated Trees in Vietnam**
The Distinctive Products They Yield
10 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
Discover
_You might be curious to know what types of plants are commonly grown in Vietnamese households. In our country, Vietnam, especially in rural areas, every family has a garden—a place where the homeowners cultivate plants to make their living space greener. Below, we will introduce to you some of the commonly grown plants in Vietnam._
## **Bamboo**
Vietnam has a hot and humid climate that’s perfect for [bamboo ](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-bamboo/)to grow fast. Bamboo is a big kind of grass, and it’s the biggest one in the world. You can find a lot of bamboo all over Vietnam.
People in Vietnam really like bamboo and use it for different things. A long time ago, they planted bamboo around their gardens to keep the soil safe and stop it from washing away. This is important because Vietnam often has strong storms. Bamboo helps to reduce the wind’s power and protects against damage from these storms.
Besides protecting, people in Vietnam use bamboo for many everyday things. They build houses and bridges with bamboo, and they also make useful kitchen tools like chopsticks and baskets from it.
In the eyes of the Vietnamese, bamboo symbolizes unity and represents the vigorous life that rises resiliently from adversity.
Bamboo is the fastest-growing plant in the world. Some types can grow an incredible three feet in just a single day!
## **Banana tree**
Bananas are a familiar and easy-to-grow plant in Vietnam. They require minimal care, and you don’t need to fertilize or water them much for normal growth. Vietnamese people utilize various parts of the banana plant for different purposes:
Bananas carry significant importance among the Vietnamese, often being a crucial fruit placed on ancestral altars during festive occasions.
Banana blossoms find use in dishes, whether mixed, stir-fried, or consumed raw.
Banana leaves serve as wrappers for [Chung cakes](https://vivavn.com/chung-cake/), a renowned traditional Vietnamese dish commonly made during celebrations.
The trunk of the banana tree becomes a source of food for pigs, chickens, and ducks.
## **Coconut tree**
[The coconut tree](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut/) is a characteristic tree in Vietnam, and you can see these trees all over the country. This resilient and economically valuable plant is easy to grow, and different parts of the coconut can be made into yummy dishes.
Coconut water is a tasty and nutritious drink loved by the Vietnamese, especially when it’s hot. It’s also used in many Vietnamese dishes. Did you know that coconut jelly, a yummy Vietnamese treat, is made from coconut water?
Coconut meat can be used to make delicious things like candied coconut ribbons, [baked coconut cracker](https://vivavn.com/topcoco-baked-coconut-cracker/), and coconut candy.
Coconut shells are used as bowls and in making traditional crafts. Some traditional Vietnamese musical instruments are even made from coconut shells.
## ****Areca Catechu****
In Vietnam, people like to plant areca catechu in front of their homes because they believe it symbolizes peace and positivity. They also think that having these palms in front of the house can protect them from bad things, bringing good luck and prosperity to the family.
The areca nut is the fruit of the areca catechu. It plays a significant role in various traditional ceremonies among the Vietnamese, including engagements, weddings, funerals, and more. In the past, there was a custom of consuming areca nuts with betel leaves, considered a means to initiate conversations and create a more comfortable atmosphere.
Areca nuts are also regarded as symbols of love, harmony, and commitment in Vietnamese married life. This is why the betel and areca nut tray is an indispensable element in every wedding. If you have the opportunity to witness a Vietnamese wedding, you’ll observe that the first exchange during the ceremony involves a betel and areca nut tray between the two families.

# Top Coco Baked Coconut Cracker: A Specialty from Da Nang That’s Simply Irresistible
We will introduce you to the renowned baked coconut cracker from Da Nang City, Vietnam.
9 min
[](https://vivavn.com/organic-products/)
Organic products
[](https://vivavn.com/coconut/)
Coconut
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lFwohfgn3A)
_Top Coco baked coconut cracker is a delicacy in Da Nang City. This cracker blends fresh coconut meat, sesame, peanuts, and more in perfect harmony. Each ingredient is meticulously prepared to maintain its original flavors, ensuring customers have an unforgettable experience._
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial "YouTube")
[](https://www.facebook.com/vivavnofficial2024 "Facebook")
[](https://www.pinterest.com/vivavnofficial/ "Pinterest")
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
### [Vietnamese Coconut Nectar: Sokfarm’s Sustainable Sweetener](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
## Introduction
As global consumers prioritize health and wellness, there’s a growing interest in all-natural snacks. Amidst this trend, Top Coco emerges as an excellent option, offering wholesome, all-natural snacks to health-conscious consumers worldwide.
Bite into a Top Coco baked coconut cracker and experience the perfect crunch! The real coconut blends seamlessly with natural ingredients like sesame seeds, peanuts, mung beans, and rice. Its aroma and rich flavor are truly distinctive, making every bite a delicious experience.
Top Coco baked coconut crackers aren’t just famous in [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam)—they are becoming known globally. They are exported to countries all over the world, including Japan, South Korea, the United States, China, Laos, Mongolia, France, and many more.
## What are Top Coco baked coconut crackers?
Imagine rectangular crackers, thin and crispy with a warm, golden-brown color– that’s the allure of Top Coco baked coconut crackers! Made with real coconut, they deliver a satisfying crunch in every bite, bursting with deliciously authentic coconut flavor.
### The main ingredient: Tam Quan coconuts
Tam Quan, Binh Dinh, is famous for coconuts
Top Coco baked coconut cracker is primarily made with coconut meat. The manufacturer carefully chooses fresh and flavorful coconuts sourced from the Tam Quan region in Binh Dinh province.
Tam Quan, located in [Binh Dinh province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh_province) in the southern central region of Vietnam, about 300km from [Da Nang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Da_Nang), is famous for its [coconuts](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut/). Tam Quan coconuts are known for their sweet and pure water, delicious and nutritious coconut flesh.
**Popular Vietnamese fruit**
Coconut is a
### The other ingredients
In addition to sourcing their main ingredient, coconuts, from Tam Quan, Binh Dinh province, Top Coco partners with farmers in Hoa Vang district, Da Nang city to cultivate and harvest peanuts and sesame seeds, creating unique baked coconut cracker products.
Most recently, they’ve collaborated with Sokfarm, a supplier of [organic coconut flower nectar](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/), to use it as an ingredient in their newest product line “COCOOL coconut lower crackers”. These crackers boast a harmonious blend of coconut meat and Vietnamese coconut nectar, without any added sugar.
## A taste of Vietnam: the allure of coconut 
Coconuts are an important ingredient in Vietnamese cuisine and culture. They are found in almost every region of the country but are especially abundant in the southern part of Vietnam.
Coconut meat is used to make many dishes, such as coconut sticky rice, candied coconut ribbons, and coconut candy. Coconut water is also an essential ingredient in many Vietnamese dishes, including caramelized pork and eggs.
In southern Vietnam, during [the Lunar New Year](https://vivavn.com/what-is-tet/), coconuts are always included in the tray of five [fruits](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/) that are offered to ancestors on the altar. This is a symbol of good luck and prosperity for the coming year.
## How Top Coco baked coconut crackers are made
### Step 1: Harvesting the coconuts
The coconuts are harvested in Tam Quan, a region in Binh Dinh province that is known for its high-quality coconuts. After harvesting, the coconuts are husked and the coconut meat is carefully extracted. The coconut meat is then transported to the factory in Da Nang city.
### Step 2: Mixing the ingredients
The fresh coconut meat is mixed with other ingredients, such as mung beans, sesame seeds, peanuts, rice flour, and glutinous rice flour. The specific ingredients vary depending on the product line. Top Coco currently offers four product lines: traditional flavor, sesame flavor, peanut flavor, and mung bean flavor.
### Step 3: Rolling out the dough
The dough is rolled out into thin sheets.
### Step 4: Baking the crackers
The crackers are baked in an oven until they are golden brown and crispy.
### Step 5: Packaging the crackers
The crackers are cooled and then packaged in individual bags.
The Top Coco Coconut Cracker Production Process
## The Top Coco story: a journey of passion and tradition
Mai Thi Y Nhi (left) and Nguyen Van Tan (right), the co-founders of the Top Coco brand.
Mai Thi Y Nhi grew up surrounded by coconut palms in Tam Quan, Vietnam. Everywhere she looked, coconuts seemed to be a part of life – used in delicious dishes, woven into everyday crafts. This deep connection with the humble coconut sparked a dream in Nhi: to create healthy snacks that showcased the goodness of her hometown’s bounty.
Nhi wasn’t just passionate about the coconut’s delicious potential; she also saw a chance to give back to the local farmers. Despite the abundance of coconuts, many growers struggled to make a decent living. This inspired Nhi’s vision: to create successful products using the region’s coconuts and, in turn, support the local community.
After moving to Da Nang City with her husband (Nguyen Van Tan), they opened a small bakery. Since 2016, the couple spent a year researching and developing the first recipe for baked coconut crackers.
However, when they first introduced their product to the market, they faced numerous challenges: consumers were indifferent to the new product, they lacked capital, and persuading retail stores and supermarkets to carry their product was difficult.
Undeterred, Nhi and her husband displayed unwavering determination. They tirelessly approached retailers, showcasing the product’s quality and deliciousness to potential customers. They continuously refined their production process, ensuring the crackers were healthy and consistently tasty.
Their hard work paid off. Customers started embracing Top Coco’s unique flavor and healthy approach. Then came a breakthrough – their first export order, all the way from Japan! It was then that they realized that their startup could survive.
Top Coco baked coconut crackers have been certified as a 4-star [OCOP](https://vivavn.com/what-is-ocop-vietnam/) product by Da Nang City, making them a specialty of the city. The crackers are exported to markets such as Japan, Korea, the US, China, Laos, Mongolia, France, and many more.
## Why you should try Top Coco baked coconut crackers
Top Coco baked coconut crackers are made with all-natural ingredients, including fresh coconut meat, rice flour, and other farm-grown products. Every step of the production process is strictly controlled, from the sourcing of raw materials to the manufacturing process. Top Coco baked coconut crackers don’t have harmful chemicals, food additives, preservatives, artificial colors, or flavorings.
Each baked coconut cracker boasts a delightful aroma and flavor, deriving from the rich taste of fresh coconut, peanuts, and sesame seeds,… With just the right amount of sweetness and a crispy texture.
## How many varieties of Top Coco baked coconut crackers are available?
With four distinct flavors to choose from, there’s something for every taste preference:
Traditional Flavor: A harmonious blend of coconut meat and Vietnamese coconut nectar, without any added sugar.
Sesame Flavor: Enjoy the perfect combination of coconut meat and sesame seeds.
Peanut Flavor: Indulge in the rich fusion of coconut meat and peanuts.
Mung Bean Flavor: Experience the unique pairing of coconut meat and mung beans.
## FAQs: Top questions about Top Coco baked coconut crackers
### What do Top Coco baked coconut crackers taste like?
Top Coco baked coconut crackers offer a pleasant coconut fragrance with a satisfying crispy texture. The flavor is perfectly balanced with a subtle sweetness, making them an enjoyable and light snack.
### What ingredients are in Top Coco baked coconut crackers?
Top Coco baked coconut crackers feature a range of natural ingredients depending on the flavor. Each variety blends coconut meat with a unique combination of ingredients:
  * **Traditional Flavor** : Coconut meat and Vietnamese coconut nectar, with no added sugar.
  * **Sesame Flavor** : A perfect mix of coconut meat and sesame seeds.
  * **Peanut Flavor** : Coconut meat fused with roasted peanuts.
  * **Mung Bean Flavor** : A distinctive combination of coconut meat and mung beans.


### How do you eat Top Coco baked coconut crackers?
Top Coco baked coconut crackers are perfect for snacking on their own, but you can also pair them with your favorite beverages like tea, or coffee. In Vietnam, Top Coco baked coconut crackers are commonly enjoyed with a cup of tea.
### What can I pair with Top Coco baked coconut crackers?
You can enjoy Top Coco baked coconut crackers on their own, or pair them with yogurt, ice cream, fruit, pudding, or whipped cream for a delicious snack or dessert.
### Are Top Coco baked coconut crackers gluten-free?
Yes, Top Coco baked coconut crackers are gluten-free. They are made without any gluten-containing ingredients, making them a suitable choice for those following a gluten-free diet. Additionally, they are non-GMO and free from food additives.
### Are Top Coco baked coconut crackers individually packaged?
Yes, each box of Top Coco baked coconut crackers contains 12 individual packets, with each packet holding 4 rectangular pieces of crackers. This packaging makes it easy to carry and helps keep the crackers fresh longer.

# Explore Son Tra Peninsula: Da Nang’s Precious Gem
We’ll take you to explore the beauty of Son Tra Peninsula in Da Nang, Vietnam.
9 min
[](https://vivavn.com/da-nang/)
Da Nang
[](https://youtu.be/pG4rMSJRpI4)
__The Son Tra Peninsula is a famous tourist spot in the city of Da Nang, renowned for its breathtaking natural scenery including untouched forests, wild coastlines, and precious rare animals. Let’s discover this gem of Da Nang in this article.__
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial "YouTube")
[](https://www.facebook.com/vivavnofficial2024 "Facebook")
[](https://www.pinterest.com/vivavnofficial/ "Pinterest")
[](https://vivavn.com/lady-buddha/)
### [Majestic Lady Buddha: Son Tra Peninsula’s Iconic Statue  
](https://vivavn.com/lady-buddha/)
## Introduction
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Son Tra Peninsula, located in Tho Quang ward, Son Tra district, is about 10 kilometers northeast of downtown Da Nang. It’s surrounded by the sea on three sides, with the remaining side bordering urban areas. Son Tra represents a unique blend of the natural forest ecosystem and the sea, making it the only place of its kind in Vietnam.
Covering an area of over 4,400 hectares, the peninsula stretches 13 kilometers with a perimeter of around 60 kilometers. It has an average elevation of 350 meters, with its highest point being Mount Oc at nearly 700 meters.
Son Tra Peninsula, Da Nang, Vietnam from Google Earth Pro
According to scientific surveys, the biodiversity of Son Tra Peninsula is rich, with over 1000 plant species, 287 mammal species, and 106 bird species. It also provides habitat for 15 rare and endangered animals needing conservation efforts. Each year, hundreds of migratory bird species travel from the north to the south to escape the cold, finding refuge in Son Tra.
## Top Attractions
### Da Nang’s Most Charming Fishing Village
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Nestled beneath Son Tra Mountain is the time-honored Man Thai fishing village, a quaint community with hospitable locals always ready with a welcoming smile for visitors. Here, the residents make a living by fishing.
The ideal time to explore this village is at dawn when the serene landscape unfolds with fishermen casting nets, boats brimming with fresh catches docking, and the lively trade of the morning’s bounty.
### Ban Co peak
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
At about 700 meters above sea level, [**Ban Co Peak**](https://vivavn.com/ban-co-peak/) is known as “Da Nang’s rooftop”. From its summit, visitors can enjoy a breathtaking panoramic view of Da Nang, offering a refreshing perspective. It’s the perfect place to relish the crisp, clean air of the mountain.
[Ban Co Peak: A Must-Visit Attraction in Da Nang City](https://vivavn.com/ban-co-peak/)
### Lady Buddha
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
This is the tallest statue of [**the Lady Buddha**](https://vivavn.com/lady-buddha/) in Vietnam, reaching a staggering height of 67 meters, equivalent to a 30-story building. The statue of the lady Buddha, also known as Quan Am, sits atop a base resembling a lotus flower, which is 35 meters wide. It was crafted over six years by some of the most talented artisans. The statue is divided into 17 floors, with each floor dedicated to honoring 21 different Buddhas.
[Majestic Lady Buddha: Son Tra Peninsula’s Iconic Statue](https://vivavn.com/lady-buddha/)
### Linh Ung pagoda
Photographer: Name. Peter
[The Linh Ung Pagoda](https://vivavn.com/linh-ung-pagoda/), also called the Linh Ung Bai But Pagoda, rests on a 20-hectare plot of land atop Son Tra Mountain. Construction of this pagoda began in 2004, and after six years of work, it was formally inaugurated on July 30, 2010, marking its completion.
Did you know? In Da Nang, there are three pagodas named Linh Ung. The largest and most famous one is Linh Ung Pagoda on Son Tra Peninsula. The second Linh Ung Pagoda is located on Ba Na Mountain, standing at 1400 meters above sea level, making it the highest among the three. The remaining Linh Ung Pagoda is situated on the Marble Mountains, being the oldest among them, constructed in the 19th century.
### Ghenh Bang
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Ghenh Bang is an untouched beach nestled on the Son Tra Peninsula. Getting there involves a trek of over 1km on rugged terrain, with steep inclines and rocky obstacles making the journey demanding. Upon completing the hike, you’ll discover a picturesque beach with pristine white sand, framed by both large and small rock formations extending into the vibrant blue sea.
### Thousand-year banyan tree
Photo credit: tuan.wildlifephoto
This towering giant is about 1000 years old and stands over 20 meters tall, with a circumference of up to 10 meters, adorned with dozens of sprawling roots. Its grandeur and beauty attract hundreds of visitors each day. Over 100 years ago, during wartime, this banyan tree provided shelter for [**Vietnamese**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnamese_language) soldiers. In June 2014, it was officially designated as part of Vietnam’s Heritage Tree system, marking it as Da Nang City’s first recognized ancient [**heritage tree**](https://danang.gov.vn/vi/web/en/detail?id=15589&_c=16407387).
### Mui Nghe (Nghe Cape)
Photo credit: Han Thanh Nam
Mui Nghe is the perfect spot to catch stunning sunrises on the Son Tra Peninsula. It’s where you welcome the first rays of daylight, surrounded by refreshing air that brings a sense of tranquility. The unique rock formations, some resembling creatures from Vietnamese folklore, add to the allure. Here, you’ll discover beautiful, serene turquoise ponds ideal for a day of relaxation. The journey to Mui Nghe is challenging and suitable for adventurous souls; you’ll trek through steep terrain and dense forests before arriving at your destination.
### Black Rock Beach
Black Rock Beach earned its name from the locals due to the abundance of large black rocks scattered across its shores. These rocks are arranged in captivating formations, offering picturesque views. Notably, the area features numerous artificial ponds nestled among the rocks. Shielded by the large formations, the water remains clear and calm throughout the year, making it ideal for swimming. Additionally, Black Rock Beach is a popular spot for camping excursions.
## Is there any wildlife to see in the wild areas of the Son Tra Peninsula?
### Monkeys
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
When you explore the Son Tra Peninsula, you’ll find yourself in a realm of lively primates – the monkeys of Son Tra. These playful creatures roam freely on the roads, swinging through the lush canopy, playing on the forest floor, or gathering around the Linh Ung Pagoda.
### The red-shanked douc langur
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
According to the biodiversity conservation center GreenViet, Son Tra is home to about 300-350 [**Red-shanked Douc Langurs**](https://vivavn.com/red-shanked-douc-langur/), making it the largest and most sustainable population of this species. With their distinctive five-color fur, they’re often referred to as the “queens” of primates. Classified as endangered (EN) on the IUCN Red List and in the Vietnam Red Data Book (2007), these langurs are shy creatures, making them elusive to spot, requiring both luck and patience.
[The Red-Shanked Douc Langur in Son Tra Peninsula](https://vivavn.com/red-shanked-douc-langur/)
### Coral reefs
Son Tra Peninsula boasts an enchanting underwater realm! Its vibrant coral reefs, teeming with diverse marine life, serve as a sanctuary for countless sea creatures. This thriving ecosystem makes Son Tra a paradise for both divers and snorkelers
## Outdoor Adventures
### Paragliding over Son Tra
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Embark on a thrilling 15 to 20-minute [**paragliding journey**](https://vivavn.com/son-tra-peninsula-paragliding/) to take in the breathtaking vistas of Da Nang city from above. Accompanied by seasoned instructors, every detail is meticulously arranged for your flight. As you soar through the skies, behold the panoramic beauty of Son Tra Peninsula’s verdant forests, the majestic Linh Ung Pagoda, and the stunning coastal beaches.
[Son Tra Peninsula paragliding: Enjoy spectacular natural views](https://vivavn.com/son-tra-peninsula-paragliding/)
### Hiking through the dense jungle trails
Experience the serene beauty of Son Tra Peninsula through invigorating hiking excursions. Wander along picturesque trails winding through verdant forests, pristine shorelines, and captivating ocean panoramas. Encounter a wealth of biodiversity, from rare flora to indigenous wildlife, while uncovering historical cultural landmarks. Whether seeking tranquility, cultural exploration, or outdoor fitness, hiking in Son Tra offers an unforgettable experience for nature enthusiasts of all levels.
### Explore Son Tra Peninsula on a scenic bike ride
Just like hiking, cycling lets you discover Son Tra Peninsula’s beauty at your own pace, offering stunning coastal views and hidden gems along the way.
### Birdwatching to spot rare bird species
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
[**Birdwatching on Son Tra**](https://vivavn.com/birdwatching-on-son-tra-peninsula/) is a captivating experience amidst the scenic beauty! Every year, as cold winds from the North bring in migration season, Son Tra Peninsula becomes a haven for migratory birds worldwide. This annual spectacle draws wildlife enthusiasts, particularly avid birdwatchers and photographers, eager to spot rare species against the backdrop of Son Tra’s stunning landscape.
[Birdwatching on Son Tra Peninsula: A journey for the curious and the patient](https://vivavn.com/birdwatching-on-son-tra-peninsula/)
### Snorkeling or diving in the crystal-clear waters
Son Tra’s marine environment is a treasure trove of diversity, especially with its stunning coral reefs. Plunge into these crystal-clear waters for an unforgettable glimpse into the bustling world beneath the surface! Whether you’re snorkeling or diving, Son Tra offers an unparalleled opportunity to encounter a variety of marine creatures.
Most of the photos in the article were taken by Huy Dope, a talented photographer who currently works at a paragliding club on Son Tra Peninsula.

# Linh Ung Pagoda: The Ultimate Guide for First-Time Travelers to Da Nang
10 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/destinations/)
Destinations
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RyR3ZKjPubA)
_If you’re visiting Da Nang for the first time and want to explore the Linh Ung Pagoda on Son Tra Peninsula, this guide is for you. In this article, we’ll take you through the must-see spots within the pagoda, the best times to visit, transportation options to get there, nearby attractions, and helpful tips for your visit. At the end, we’ve also included a section with frequently asked questions to help you plan your trip with ease_
[](https://vivavn.com/linh-ung-pagoda/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/linh-ung-pagoda/#comment "Comment")
Overview
Getting to Linh Ung Pagoda

_Watch our video showcasing the beauty of Linh Ung Pagoda._
## What to know about Linh Ung Pagoda
### What is Linh Ung Pagoda famous for?
Linh Ung Pagoda, also known as Linh Ung Bai But Pagoda, is renowned for its spiritual significance, stunning architecture, and beautiful views of Da Nang. The highlight is the towering 67-meter-tall [Lady Buddha statue](https://vivavn.com/lady-buddha/), the tallest in Vietnam. Surrounded by lush greenery and overlooking the vast ocean, the pagoda offers a serene atmosphere for visitors seeking peace and spiritual connection.
**Did you know?** There are three Linh Ung Pagodas in Da Nang. The one on Son Tra Peninsula is the largest and most famous, and locals also refer to it as Linh Ung Bai But Pagoda. The Linh Ung Pagoda in Marble Mountains is the oldest, while the one on Ba Na Mountain is the highest, standing at 1,400 meters above sea level.
### What are the highlights of this pagoda?
Here are some must-see attractions at Linh Ung Pagoda:
**Lady Buddha Statue** : This 67-meter statue is a symbol of protection for fishermen and the city of Da Nang. 
**Bonsai Garden:** A peaceful space with hundreds of carefully nurtured bonsai trees, each with its own unique beauty and charm.
**The Main Hall:** A sacred space featuring traditional Vietnamese architecture, where visitors come to pray and find peace.
**Main Gate:** Grand and majestic, it’s a popular spot for visitors to take photos.
**Xa Loi Tower:** A striking nine-story structure reflecting the timeless beauty of Vietnamese Buddhist architecture.
Linh Ung Pagoda sits about 200 meters above sea level, and there are plenty of spots around the temple where you can take in beautiful views of both the ocean and Da Nang city.
### Linh Ung Pagoda opening hours
The pagoda is open daily from 5:00 AM to 9:00 PM
### Linh Ung Pagoda entrance fee
There is no entrance fee to visit the pagoda. Admission is free for all visitors.
### How long to spend at Linh Ung Pagoda?
The pagoda is a large complex with many attractions to explore, and we recommend spending at least 1.5-2 hours there to fully enjoy its beauty and take photos.
Video about Linh Ung Pagoda Son Tra Da Nang by [Vivavn ](https://vivavn.com)Team
## How to get to Linh Ung Pagoda?
The pagoda is located on [Son Tra Peninsula](https://vivavn.com/son-tra-peninsula/), about 10 kilometers from Da Nang city center. Here are the best ways to get there:
**By car or taxi** : A convenient 15-minute drive from Da Nang.
**By motorbike** : Enjoy a scenic ride along coastal roads.
**By bicycle:** A fun and eco-friendly option, allowing you to explore the peninsula at your own pace.
**By walking:** For adventure seekers, a hike from the base of Son Tra Peninsula offers a close connection to nature.
**By tour:** Many local operators offer guided trips with transportation included.
Linh Ung Pagoda is about 10 km from both the city center and My Khe Beach. We recommend you try biking, riding a motorbike, or even walking to the pagoda. Along the way, you’ll be treated to stunning views, like the coastal road at the base of Son Tra Mountain with hundreds of basket boats, the peaceful Green Lake, and several spots perfect for taking in the ocean view. You might even spot some monkeys along the way!
## Top attractions near Linh Ung Temple
To fully enjoy the beauty of Son Tra Peninsula, don’t miss the beautiful attractions near this pagoda. From peaceful lakes to lovely beaches, we suggest you take the time to explore!
**Green Lake (Ho Xanh):** A peaceful and serene spot to relax and enjoy nature’s tranquility, situated about 3 km before you reach the pagoda.
**Rock Beach (Bai Da):** A coastal area with unique rock formations, located about 5 km from this pagoda.
**Ghenh Bang Beach (Ghenh Bang):** A pristine, less-crowded beach perfect for exploring and unwinding. Located more than 10 km from the pagoda, it requires a walk of over 1 km down a forest trail after parking your vehicle, which can be quite challenging.
**Thousand-Year-Old Banyan Tree (Cay Da Ngan Nam):** A majestic ancient tree with a rich history, perfect for photo opportunities.
**Nghe Cape (Mui Nghe):** Situated at the easternmost point of Son Tra Peninsula, this location features a large rock formation resembling a sea lion and a beautiful natural swimming pool. However, the route to reach it is challenging, and it’s easy to get lost without a local guide.
The Thousand-Year-Old Banyan Tree and Nghe Cape are located in areas prone to landslides, and local authorities often restrict access for safety reasons, especially during the rainy season. However, there are certain times of the year when visits are allowed. Be sure to check with on-site security personnel to confirm if access is permitted during your visit.
Video about the beautiful spots on Son Tra Peninsula by Vivavn Team
## What is the best time to visit Linh Ung Pagoda?
Photo credit: Sunset (Tăng Trung Kiên/baodanang), Sunrise (Phạm Phùng/vnexpress), Rainy day (Thanh Hiền/tienphong), Dry day and Evening (Nguyễn Hồng Huy)
Here’s a quick guide to the best moments of the year and day, with some pros and cons to help you decide what feels just right.
### **Best time of year to visit the pagoda**
**Pros**
**Cons**
January to August (Dry Season)
– The weather is dry, sunny, and perfect for sightseeing.  
  
– Clear skies and vibrant natural surroundings enhance the overall experience.
– Midday temperatures, especially from 10 AM to 3 PM, can get quite hot, particularly during the summer months of May to July.  
  
– High tourist traffic during the peak summer season.
September to December (Rainy Season)
– Cooler and more comfortable weather on days without rain.
– Rainy days can make it difficult to fully enjoy the scenery and outdoor areas.  
  
– Overcast skies may limit visibility, and the ocean view loses some of its usual vibrancy.
### **Best time of day to visit Linh Ung Pagoda**
The pagoda offers a serene and beautiful atmosphere throughout the day. However, if you’re looking for the most memorable experiences, the best times to visit are at sunrise, sunset, or even in the evening.
**Sunrise (5–6 AM):**
Enjoy a peaceful atmosphere and stunning views of the sunrise over the ocean.
**Sunset (5–6 PM):**
Witness the breathtaking golden hues of the sunset
**Evening (before 9 PM):**
Experience the tranquil ambiance as the Lady Buddha statue is illuminated, creating a mystical and majestic appearance.
## Are there any wildlife species near Linh Ung Temple?
Linh Ung Pagoda, located on the Son Tra Peninsula, is surrounded by pristine forests that are home to many rare plant and animal species. Here are some animals you might encounter around the pagoda:
**Monkeys:** These are commonly spotted along the roads or in the trees. They are easy to spot.
**Red-shanked Douc Langurs:** A rare and beautiful species, these monkeys are often found high in the trees. They’re shy, so spotting them can be challenging.
**Birds:** You’ll likely spot some birds around the pagoda.
**Note:** Monkeys on the Son Tra Peninsula are quite curious and often come up to ask for food. They have been known to steal things, so make sure to keep your belongings safe—hold onto your keys, phone, and snacks!
## Tips for visiting Linh Ung Pagoda Da Nang
### **Weather tips**
**On sunny days:**
Bring a hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen to protect yourself from the heat. The open spaces around the pagoda can get quite sunny, so staying hydrated is important. You can bring your own water or grab a drink from one of the refreshment stands inside the pagoda grounds.
**On rainy days:**
Pack a lightweight raincoat or umbrella to stay dry, as the area can get slippery. Comfortable, non-slip shoes are a must, especially if you plan to explore the gardens and walkways.
### **Linh Ung Pagoda dress code**
**Dress modestly:**
Since the pagoda is a sacred site, it’s respectful to wear modest clothing. Lightweight, breathable fabrics are a great choice for staying comfortable.
**Comfortable shoes:**
When you’re visiting Linh Ung Pagoda, it’s a good idea to wear shoes that are easy to slip off, since you’ll need to take them off when entering the more sacred areas, like the main hall. And with all the walking around, make sure to choose comfortable, non-slip shoes. Slip-on shoes or sandals with straps are perfect for both convenience and comfort.
### **Transportation tips**
You can use an automatic scooter to get to the pagoda, but note that automatic scooters aren’t allowed to access some other attractions on Son Tra Peninsula, like the Thousand-Year-Old Banyan Tree or [Ban Co Peak](https://vivavn.com/ban-co-peak/). If you plan to visit these places after the pagoda, it’s better to choose a semi-automatic scooter instead.
Also, make sure to check your fuel tank, as there are no gas stations on the peninsula. It’s a good idea to inspect your tires to ensure they are properly inflated, as there are no air pumps available. Don’t forget to check the brakes as well, since the roads include some steep areas.
This sign is located at the foot of Son Tra Mountain and indicates that automatic scooters are prohibited 9 kilometers ahead. This means you can still use an automatic scooter to reach Linh Ung Pagoda, which is only 3 kilometers from the foot of the mountain, as well as at places like Rock Beach and Ghenh Bang Beach. However, certain spots, such as the Ancient Banyan Tree (Cay Da Ngan nam) and Mui Nghe (Nghe Cape), do not allow automatic scooters.
### **Cash tips**
It’s a good idea to bring some Vietnamese cash with you. At Linh Ung Pagoda, parking is free, but for other attractions on Son Tra Peninsula, you’ll need to pay for parking. Also, if you plan to buy drinks or snacks, some shops may not accept card payments, so having cash on hand can be useful.
### **Monkey spotting tips**
Monkeys can appear in the Linh Ung Pagoda area, but the most common spots to see them are along the coconut trees about 5km away from the pagoda and near the entrance of the InterContinental Danang Sun Peninsula Resort, which is around 8km from the pagoda.
### **Monkey alert**
Be cautious around the monkeys. They are known to beg for food and can sometimes steal your belongings. Keep your items secure and avoid feeding them to prevent any unwanted situations.
The monkeys at Ghenh Bang are notorious for grabbing food, keys, or phones. Always stay alert when you’re in this area to avoid any issues.
## Common FAQs
### Where is Linh Ung Pagoda located?
**Answer:** Linh Ung Pagoda is located on the Son Tra Peninsula in Da Nang, Vietnam. It is situated approximately 10 kilometers from the city center and is surrounded by lush greenery and scenic views of the coast and mountains.
### When was Linh Ung Bai But Pagoda built?
**Answer:** Construction of Linh Ung Bai But Pagoda began in 2004 and was completed in 2010. It has since become a spiritual and architectural landmark on Son Tra Peninsula in Da Nang.
### Is there an entrance fee for Linh Ung Pagoda?
**Answer:** No, there is no entrance fee for visiting Linh Ung Pagoda. The visit is free of charge.
### Is Lady Buddha worth visiting?
**Answer:** Absolutely! The Lady Buddha statue is not only the tallest in Vietnam, standing at 67 meters, but it also offers stunning views of Da Nang and the ocean. It’s a peaceful and spiritual spot that’s worth the visit for both its impressive size and the serene atmosphere it provides.
### What time does Lady Buddha open?
**Answer:** The Lady Buddha statue is located within the Linh Ung Pagoda grounds, so it follows the same opening hours, from 5:00 AM to 9:00 PM daily.
### Do I need a guide to visit Linh Ung Pagoda Son Tra Peninsula?
**Answer:** While it’s not necessary to have a guide to visit this pagoda, having one can enhance your experience. A guide can provide valuable insights into the history, architecture, and significance of the pagoda, as well as the surrounding area. However, if you prefer exploring on your own, the pagoda is easy to navigate with clear signage and information available.
### Can I take photos inside the main hall of Linh Ung Pagoda?
**Answer:** Yes, you can take photos inside the main hall of the pagoda, but it’s recommended to avoid using flash as a sign of respect to others who may be praying. Outside the main hall and in the surrounding areas, feel free to capture the stunning views and architecture.
### Do I need to take off my shoes before entering the main hall?
**Answer:** Yes, the main hall is the most sacred area where people come to pray, so it’s recommended to remove your shoes before entering.
### Is there parking available at Linh Ung Temple?
**Answer:** Yes, there is parking available at Linh Ung Pagoda.
### Do I need to pay for parking at Linh Ung Temple?
**Answer:** No, parking for bicycles and motorbikes is free at Linh Ung Pagoda.
### Can I walk to Linh Ung Pagoda from My Khe Beach?
**Answer:** Yes, you can walk to Linh Ung Pagoda from My Khe Beach. The distance is about 10 km, and the walk takes approximately 1.5 hours. The route is easy and scenic, with beautiful views along the way. Just make sure you’re in good physical condition for the walk.

# Vietnamese Passion Fruit: All You Need to Know About This Fruit
7 min
[](https://vivavn.com/fruit/)
Fruit
[](https://youtu.be/uZyr7KvQMvs)
_Vietnamese passion fruit may look a bit unusual at first glance—with its round, purple skin and slightly wrinkled surface—but inside, you’ll find a golden pulp with a tangy-sweet flavor and refreshing tropical aroma. In this article, we’ll take a closer look at both the outside and inside of this unique fruit, explore how it tastes, walk through its key ripening stages, and share a few easy, delicious ways to enjoy it._
[](https://vivavn.com/passion-fruit/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/passion-fruit/#comment "Comment")
What is Vietnamese passion fruit?
How to eat Vietnamese passion fruit
Popular ways to enjoy it
Frequently asked questions
## What is Vietnamese passion fruit?
**Overview**
**Vietnamese name:** chanh day/ chanh leo
**Shape and appearance:** round or oval; smooth purple skin when ripe, sometimes with natural white specks.
**Flavor profile:** tart and citrusy with a hint of sweetness; aromatic and refreshing.
**How to enjoy it:** in Vietnam, passion fruit is enjoyed fresh, as juice, in desserts, or made into soft-dried fruit snacks.
### What does a Vietnamese passion fruit look like?
Vietnamese passion fruit can be either round or oval in shape, and its appearance might surprise you if you’ve never seen one before. Most varieties grown in [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam) have deep purple skin when ripe, sometimes with natural white specks on the surface — that’s completely normal.
Typically, the fruits measure around 4 to 8 centimeters (about 1.5 to 3.1 inches) in diameter. When freshly ripe, the skin is smooth and glossy. As the fruit becomes sweeter and more aromatic, the skin begins to wrinkle, which is actually a good sign.
_Green Vietnamese passion fruits in their early ripening stage, hanging on the vine and not yet ready to eat._
_Glossy purple passion fruit ripening on the vine in a Vietnamese garden._
_Typical size of ripe Vietnamese passion fruit — about 5 cm in diameter._
_From left to right: unripe green passion fruit, ripe purple fruit with smooth skin, and fully ripe fruit with wrinkled skin._
Take a look at the photo above to see the three common stages of ripeness:
**Unripe** : Green skin with white specks. The fruit is still firm and not ready to eat—pulp inside is too sour and underdeveloped.
**Ripe** : Smooth purple skin. This is the standard ripe stage, and the fruit is ready to eat with a sweet-tart flavor that’s refreshing and balanced.
**Fully ripe** : Wrinkled purple skin with softer pulp inside. At this stage, the flavor is sweeter, more aromatic, and less tangy—many people actually prefer eating passion fruit when it looks a little wrinkled like this.
**Tip:** For eating fresh, pick a passion fruit that feels heavy for its size and has slightly wrinkled skin—it’s usually sweeter and more flavorful.
_Harvesting a ripe Vietnamese passion fruit by hand_
### What’s inside a Vietnamese passion fruit?
When you cut open a Vietnamese passion fruit, you’ll find three distinct layers. The thick outer skin is firm and often a deep purple color when ripe. Just beneath the skin is a soft, spongy white layer called the pith. While it’s not typically eaten, this layer helps protect the fruit’s flavorful center.
At the core is the golden pulp — a juicy, jelly-like filling packed with edible black seeds. This pulp is where all the flavor lives: sweet, tart, aromatic, and tropical. The seeds add a crunchy texture and are safe (and common) to eat along with the pulp.
_A look inside a Vietnamese passion fruit showing the thick skin, white pith, and golden pulp with edible seeds._
### What does Vietnamese passion fruit taste like?
Vietnamese passion fruit has a bright, tropical flavor with a mix of tartness and subtle sweetness. When freshly cut, the first thing you’ll notice is its signature tang — a sharp, citrusy sourness that’s refreshing rather than overpowering.
As the fruit ripens, a natural sweetness begins to emerge, softening the acidity and creating a more rounded, balanced flavor.
_Golden pulp and black seeds of a ripe Vietnamese passion fruit — bold, tangy, and tropical._
**Tip:** Wrinkled skin usually means the passion fruit is ripe, fragrant, and sweeter — many Vietnamese people prefer it this way.
Just avoid any fruit with mold, or a sour smell — that’s a sign it’s gone bad.
## How to eat Vietnamese passion fruit
Vietnamese passion fruit is easy to enjoy, whether you’re eating it fresh or adding it to your favorite recipes. Here’s a simple step-by-step guide to help you get the most out of this tropical fruit, complete with real photos.
### Step 1: Wash the fruit
Before cutting, rinse the passion fruit under cool water to remove any dirt or debris. The outer skin isn’t eaten, but keeping things clean is always a good start.
### Step 2: Slice it in half
Use a sharp knife to slice it in half. The outer skin is thick but cuts easily with a bit of pressure.
### **Step 3: Reveal the golden pulp**
Once cut open, you’ll see the bright yellow-orange pulp filled with small black seeds. This is the edible part of the fruit — juicy, aromatic, and full of flavor.
### **Step 4: Scoop out the pulp**
Grab a spoon and scoop the pulp straight from the shell. You can eat it fresh or use it to make drinks and desserts.
### **Step 5: Serve or store**
Scoop the pulp into a glass cup if you’re using it in smoothies or drinks. You can enjoy it right away or refrigerate it for later use.
## Popular ways to enjoy Vietnamese passion fruit
### **Passion fruit juice**
In Vietnam, passion fruit juice is a simple, well-loved drink, especially during the hot summer months. It’s easy to make and packed with natural flavor.
To prepare it, you just cut open a ripe passion fruit, scoop the pulp into a glass, add some cool water, and stir in a bit of sugar or honey to taste. Toss in a handful of ice cubes, and that’s it — you’ve got a refreshing, tangy-sweet drink that’s both hydrating and full of tropical aroma.
_Vietnamese passion fruit juice with honey and ice_
### **Soft-dried Vietnamese passion fruit**
Ripe passion fruit is slowly dried to reduce its sourness and bring out a mellow sweetness. Its natural aroma and flavor are preserved, resulting in a chewy snack with a bright, balanced taste.
Soft-dried passion fruit is a popular Vietnamese treat — slightly sweet, tangy, and full of tropical flavor. It’s a great option for anyone who enjoys natural fruit snacks and one of the most distinctive choices among Vietnamese dried fruits.
_A slice of soft-dried Vietnamese passion fruit showing its chewy texture and brown color_
**Want to try it yourself?**
[Here’s a soft-dried passion fruit snack available on Amazon](https://amzn.to/3I2sKH3) — a lovely option if you’d like to experience how it’s enjoyed in Vietnam. _(This is an affiliate link, which means I may earn a small commission if you make a purchase — at no additional cost to you.)_
### **Fresh passion fruit with honey**
Another easy way to enjoy Vietnamese passion fruit is to eat it straight from the shell, with a little honey added right inside. Just cut the fruit in half, drizzle a spoonful of honey over the pulp, and scoop it out with a spoon. You can also scoop the pulp into a glass, stir in honey to taste, and enjoy it that way.
This method brings out a softer sweetness while keeping the fruit’s bright, tropical flavor. No prep needed — just fresh, simple, and satisfying.
_A little honey turns this Vietnamese passion fruit into a sweet, spoon-ready treat._
## Frequently asked questions about Vietnamese passion fruit
### What does Vietnamese passion fruit taste like?
The taste is bright, tangy, and tropical, with a citrus-like tartness that becomes softer and sweeter as the fruit ripens. When combined with honey or sugar, it transforms into a balanced, refreshing treat.
### How do you know when Vietnamese passion fruit is ripe?
A ripe Vietnamese passion fruit will have deep purple skin that’s either smooth or slightly wrinkled. The more wrinkled it is, the sweeter and more aromatic the pulp tends to be.
### Can you eat Vietnamese passion fruit seeds?
Yes, the black seeds inside the pulp are generally considered edible. Some people eat them along with the juicy pulp, as they add a bit of texture. Others prefer to strain the seeds out and use just the liquid and pulp. If you have any concerns or digestive sensitivities, it’s a good idea to check with your doctor first.

# Pho Trach Traditonal Sedge Weaving Village
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
4 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/eco-friendly-products/)
Eco-friendly products
[](https://vivavn.com/category/grey-sedge/)
Grey sedge
_Pho Trach village is a small village located about 50 kilometers north of Hue city in Vietnam. The village is famous for weaving[ eco-friendly products](https://vivavn.com/vietnam-eco-friendly-products/) from grey sedge (cỏ bàng) that grows in the local wetlands. Their products are known for their durability and beauty, and they are popular souvenirs for tourists visiting Vietnam._
## Unveiling the history of Pho Trach’s sedge weaving
Pho Trach village was founded in the mid-1400s. For centuries, the villagers have made a living by farming [rice](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-organic-rice/). During the off-season, they earn additional income by weaving products from grey sedge.
Pho Trach Village is located in a coastal plain area. The area has low-lying areas that are flooded year-round, which makes it a good place for grey sedge grass to grow. In the past, the villagers noticed that wild grey sedge grass could be used to weave beautiful and durable sleeping mats. They started planting sedge grass on the edges of their rice fields. They harvested it once a year, dried it, and stored it carefully so they could use it throughout the year.
In Pho Trach village, the art of sedge mat weaving is passed down from generation to generation. Parents teach their children how to weave sedge, and even women who marry into the village learn how to weave mats.
Beyond their traditional craft of weaving mats for sale, the villagers of Pho Trach have channeled their skills and creativity into a variety of new products. Now they offer fashionable items like bags, hats, and caps, as well as beautiful home decor pieces.
