# Vietnamese Eco-Friendly Products: Discover Sustainable Solutions
We’re excited to share fascinating information about eco-friendly products from Vietnam!
10 min
[](https://vivavn.com/eco-friendly-products/)
Eco-friendly products
_Looking for ways to ditch plastic and embrace sustainability? Look no further than Vietnam! From remote villages to bustling cities, this vibrant country is brimming with eco-friendly products that are both good for the planet and seriously cool._
## Vietnamese eco-friendly bamboo products
[Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam) thrives on bamboo! It’s everywhere you look, and for centuries, Vietnamese people have been using it to craft all sorts of eco-friendly products. From tiny villages like [Bao La bamboo knitting village](https://vivavn.com/bao-la-bamboo-knitting-village/) in Hue, where families have been weaving bamboo for generations, to young, passionate entrepreneurs launching green startups like [Dalat Bamboo](https://vivavn.com/dalat-bamboo/), bamboo is deeply woven into Vietnamese culture and innovation.
Forget about chopsticks! [Vietnamese bamboo](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-bamboo/) crafts go way beyond, offering an incredible range of eco-friendly products. From cutlery sets you’ll love using every day to vibrant home decor that brings nature indoors, and even stylish fashion accessories for you and your furry friends, bamboo’s versatility is truly amazing.
## Vietnamese areca leaf eco-products
The areca leaf sheath is the petiole of the areca palm leaf that wraps around the trunk of the areca palm. They are thin and flat, with a fibrous tissue structure. The size of the leaf sheath varies depending on the size of the palm tree, typically ranging from 20 to 30 cm in width and 50 to 60 cm in length, with a thickness of about 1 to 2 mm. When the areca palm leaf withers and falls off, the areca leaf sheath also falls off. At this point, it is usually dry and very tough.
Imagine plates made from leaves, bags woven from nature’s scraps, and decorations that breathe life into your home – all thanks to Vietnamese ingenuity! Startups are [transforming discarded areca leaf sheaths](https://vivavn.com/areca-leaf-sheaths/) into these amazing eco-friendly products, proving that sustainability can be both beautiful and practical.
## Vietnamese coconut products
[Coconut ](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut/)is one of the most [widely cultivated plants in Vietnam](https://vivavn.com/the-most-cultivated-trees-in-vietnam/). While the coconut fruit is a [beloved Vietnamese fruit](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/), other parts of the coconut tree are also utilized by Vietnamese artisans to create beautiful and eco-friendly products. Using the [coconut shell](https://vivavn.com/coconut-shell-products/), wood, leaves, stalks, bark, and fiber, they craft stunning items for the kitchen and home decor.
## Vietnamese eco-friendly products from sugarcane bagasse
Sugarcane juice tastes sweet and refreshing, but did you know it has more to offer? After squeezing out the juice, there’s leftover stuff called sugarcane bagasse. In Vietnam, people are finding clever ways to use this leftover material for eco-friendly purposes. It’s becoming a big deal in sustainable living!
Imagine swapping out your plastic plates for strong, heat-resistant ones made entirely from sugarcane bagasse. Think of handy food containers and even utensils, all with the same eco-friendly features. These Vietnamese creations aren’t just nice to look at; they show how clever we can be and our dedication to a greener world.
## Vietnamese eco-friendly products from sedge grass
Grey sedge, also known as cỏ bàng in Vietnamese, is a versatile plant that thrives in wetland areas. In Vietnam, it can be found abundantly in the Mekong Delta and in[ the village of Pho Trach ](https://vivavn.com/pho-trach-traditonal-sedge-weaving-village/)near Hue City.
Grey sedge is widely used by Vietnamese artisans to create beautiful and functional products. These include home decor items such as fruit baskets, decorative carpets, and floor pillows, as well as fashion accessories such as bags, hats, and wallets. In recent years, grey sedge has also been used as an eco-friendly alternative to plastic straws.
## Vietnamese eco-friendly products from coffee grounds
Did you know Vietnam reigns supreme as the world’s second-largest coffee exporter? With such a deep love for the brew, Vietnamese people naturally go through a mountain of coffee grounds each year.
But instead of letting them go to waste, a Vietnamese company called Veritas is breathing new life into these grounds by transforming them into something remarkable: stylish and sustainable cups, mugs, cutlery and more!
## Vietnamese **eco-friendly loofah**
Have you ever wondered about the origin of those [loofah sponges?](https://vivavn.com/what-is-a-loofah/) Well, they actually grow on a fascinating plant called luffa, which thrives in tropical regions like Vietnam. When the luffa fruit is young, it’s a tasty and nutritious vegetable. But if it’s allowed to fully ripen, something remarkable happens.
Rather than going to waste, the mature luffa fruit develops tough fibers that are perfect for making natural sponges, shower brushes, and even dishwashing scrubbers! Vietnamese people have been using these versatile loofah products for centuries, and now they’re gaining popularity worldwide as a sustainable and eco-friendly alternative to traditional options.

# What Is Water Spinach? A Guide to This Asian Super Green
6 min
Vegetables
[](https://youtu.be/aIblzF4ZdRI)
_Have you ever seen long, hollow-stemmed greens in a stir-fry at an Asian restaurant and wondered what they are? That’s water spinach—also known as kang kong, ong choy, or rau muong in Vietnamese. Loved for its tender stems and fast growth, this leafy vegetable is a staple across Southeast Asia. In this article, we’ll explore everything you need to know about water spinach: its unique characteristics, how it’s grown and harvested, its nutritional benefits, and how it’s used in traditional Vietnamese cuisine._
[](https://vivavn.com/water-spinach/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/water-spinach/#comment "Comment")
What is water spinach
Growing and harvesting
Nutrition facts
Culinary uses
FAQs
## What is water spinach?
**Overview**
**Vietnamese name:** _rau muong_
**Shape and appearance:** Long, hollow stems divided by nodes, soft in texture, and green or purplish in color. Leaves vary in shape—some are arrowhead-like with pointed tips, while others are narrow and elongated. 
**Habitat** : Grows both on land and in water.
**How to enjoy it:** In Vietnamese cuisine, it’s commonly stir-fried with garlic, boiled and served with dipping sauce, or cooked into soup with shrimp.
**Harvest season:** Grown year-round in Vietnam, thanks to its fast growth and adaptability.
### **Two main types of water spinach in Vietnam:**
There are two main types of water spinach in Vietnam: upland (dryland) water spinach, which is commonly grown in home gardens, and aquatic water spinach, typically grown in ponds or flooded fields, often with longer stems and the ability to be harvested multiple times. Both types are used similarly in cooking, though the aquatic variety is more common in large-scale farming.
_Image_ : _A row of fresh upland Vietnamese water spinach growing in soil_
_Image: Aquatic water spinach growing in a pond in Vietnam_
#### Leaf shape: upland vs aquatic varieties
Depending on growing conditions, water spinach develops two distinct leaf types. The upland variety, often grown in soil, tends to have slender, elongated leaves. The aquatic variety, which thrives in water, produces shorter, arrowhead-shaped leaves with pointed tips.
_Image: Close-up of upland water spinach leaves—long, narrow, and vibrant green_
_Image: Close-up of aquatic water spinach with arrowhead-shaped leaves growing in water_
#### Stem characteristics: upland vs aquatic types
Both kinds of water spinach have hollow stems with clear segments. But the way they grow makes a big difference. The upland type, which grows in soil, has slimmer, straighter stems that are light green. The water-grown variety has thicker stems that are heavier and float on water. These stems can be green or purple.
_Image: Close-up of upland water spinach stems growing in soil_
_Close-up of aquatic water spinach stems growing in water_
## **Cultivating and harvesting water spinach**
In Vietnam’s tropical climate, water spinach grows easily, whether it’s cultivated on dry land or in wet conditions. Both types are typically grown from seeds, though the water-grown variety can also be propagated from cuttings. After just 20 to 25 days, the plants are ready for harvest. For upland water spinach, farmers usually harvest the entire plant.
But when it comes to the water-grown kind, they use scissors to cut the stems, leaving about 7 to 10 centimeters at the base. This allows the plant to regrow and be harvested again several more times.
_Vietnamese farmer preparing the soil for planting water spinach in a home garden._
_Vietnamese farmer harvesting upland water spinach by hand after 20 days of growth._
## **Nutritional benefits of water spinach**
Water spinach isn’t just a popular leafy green in Vietnamese cuisine—it’s also full of nutrients that support overall health. With its high water content, low calories, and a good range of essential vitamins and minerals, this vegetable is a refreshing and nourishing choice in everyday meals.
Here’s the nutritional breakdown for a 3.5-ounce (100-gram) serving of raw water spinach (_Ipomoea aquatica_ , also known as _water convolvulus_), based on [USDA data](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/food-details/169301/nutrients):
**Nutrient** | **Amount** | **Notes**  
---|---|---  
Water | 92.5 g | High water content helps keep you hydrated.  
Energy | 19 kcal | A very low-calorie food.  
Protein | 2.6 g | Provides a modest amount of protein.  
Fiber | 2.1 g | Supports healthy digestion.  
Vitamin C | 55 mg | Contributes to immune function.  
Vitamin A (RAE) | 315 µg | Important for vision.  
Potassium | 312 mg | Helps regulate fluid balance.  
Calcium | 77 mg | Contributes to bone and dental health.  
Iron | 1.67 mg | Needed for red blood cell production.  
Magnesium | 71 mg | Plays a role in muscle and nerve function.  
## Culinary uses
Water spinach is a staple in everyday Vietnamese cooking. It’s one of the most common leafy greens found in home kitchens and local eateries across the country. Despite being prepared in simple ways, dishes made with water spinach are packed with flavor, offering freshness and balance to the meal.
###  **Stir-fried water spinach with garlic** (rau muong xao toi)
This is one of those everyday dishes that feels comforting no matter how many times you’ve had it. The garlic is gently sautéed to bring out its aroma, then the water spinach is quickly stir-fried until tender but still crisp. Lightly seasoned the Vietnamese way, it’s a simple yet flavorful side that always hits the spot, especially with a bowl of warm rice.
_Freshly stir-fried water spinach with garlic—crisp, aromatic, and full of flavor. A beloved side dish in everyday Vietnamese meals._
###  **Water spinach soup with shrimp (canh rau muong nau voi tom)**  

Water spinach soup with shrimp is a beloved everyday dish in Vietnamese homes. It’s light, flavorful, and comes together quickly—perfect for a family meal. The recipe starts with peeled shrimp, which are sautéed with garlic, shallots, and a touch of oil. A splash of [fish sauce](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fish-sauce/) adds that signature depth of flavor common in Vietnamese cooking.
Once the shrimp are fragrant and just cooked, water is added to create the broth. Finally, fresh water spinach is tossed in and gently simmered until just tender. The result is a refreshing, slightly savory soup that pairs beautifully with steamed rice.
_A classic Vietnamese soup made with fresh water spinach and shrimp—simple, nourishing, and full of flavor._
###  **Boiled water spinach with soy sauce**(rau muong luoc cham nuoc tuong)  

Boiled water spinach with soy sauce is a humble yet delicious staple in Vietnamese home cooking. It’s incredibly simple: fresh water spinach is briefly boiled until just tender, then served with a small bowl of soy sauce for dipping. For extra flavor, thinly sliced garlic and chili can be added to the soy sauce, creating a savory and slightly spicy dip. This dish is often enjoyed with plain rice, offering a clean, refreshing contrast to richer main courses.
_Classic Vietnamese side: boiled water spinach served with soy sauce, garlic, and chili_
## Frequently asked questions about water spinach
### **What is water spinach?**
Known as **rau muong** in Vietnam, it’s got **hollow, jointed stems** and arrowhead-shaped or long, slender leaves. It grows like a weed – literally – in both **waterlogged paddies** and **dry garden beds**. Mild flavor, crazy versatility, and a  _staple_ in every Vietnamese home kitchen. 
### **Are there different varieties of water spinach?**
Yes, there are mainly two types: upland (dryland) water spinach with slender, elongated leaves, and aquatic water spinach with broader, arrowhead-shaped leaves.
### **How is water spinach commonly prepared?**
It’s versatile in cooking—commonly stir-fried with garlic, added to soups, or simply boiled and served with dipping sauces. Its tender stems and leaves absorb flavors well.
### **Can I grow water spinach at home?**
Yes, you can grow water spinach at home, especially if you live in a warm and humid place. It loves sunlight and grows well in moist soil or water. Just be sure to check your local rules first—some areas consider it invasive.
### Is water spinach safe to eat raw?
While it’s possible to eat water spinach raw, it’s generally recommended to cook it to eliminate potential contaminants, especially if sourced from the wild or unknown water sources.

# Vietnam Dried Fruits: The Best Ones You Should Try
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/dried-fruit/)
Dried fruit
[](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLr3SJJhyIBpbKillGwF0bqfXAJ0DeBtFT)
_Tropical, sweet, and packed with flavor, Vietnam dried fruits are gaining attention around the world. We’ve carefully selected the best varieties for this list, so whether you’re new to dried fruit or a long-time fan, these are the ones truly worth trying._
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnam-dried-fruits/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnam-dried-fruits/#comment "Comment")
Dried dragon fruit
Dried passion fruit
Dried rambutan
Dried mango
Dried jackfruit

FAQs
_Dear reader, we enjoy all these Vietnam dried fruits, and we took all the photos and videos in this post ourselves. This article includes affiliate links. If you find them useful and make a purchase, it helps support this website at no extra cost to you. Thank you!_
## Dried dragon fruit
_Fresh red dragon fruit is the ingredient used to make dried dragon fruit_
_Freeze-dried dragon fruit slices_
**Taste:** Lightly sweet, slightly tangy, and refreshing.
**Texture:** Dry and crisp, with a light, airy crunch.
**How to enjoy:** As a snack, in smoothies, or paired with drinks.
[Dried dragon fruit](https://vivavn.com/dried-dragon-fruit/) is made from [fresh Vietnamese dragon](https://vivavn.com/dragon-fruit/) fruit through a freeze-drying process. This method helps preserve its vibrant color, subtle sweetness, and mild tropical flavor without the need for added sugar or preservatives. The result is a crisp, light snack that closely reflects the taste and appearance of the original fruit.
If you’re curious to try it, **[this version on Amazon](https://amzn.to/4loBlCS)** is worth checking out.
_Watch our video on dried dragon fruit._
## Dried passion fruit
_Ripe Vietnamese passion fruit is the ingredient used to make dried passion fruit._
_A slice of soft-dried Vietnamese passion fruit_
**Taste:** A balanced blend of sweet and tart, with a subtle floral aroma.
**Texture:** Soft and chewy, with crunchy seeds for added texture.
**How to enjoy:** As a snack on its own.
[Passion fruit](https://vivavn.com/passion-fruit/) has a thick, deep purple rind and a golden pulp filled with jelly-like flesh and crunchy black seeds. When slowly dried, its tartness softens, giving way to a more mellow sweetness. The process helps preserve its natural aroma, resulting in a chewy, slightly tangy snack with just the right balance of texture and taste.
We recommend enjoying it with [Vietnam herbal tea](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-herbal-tea/) – like hibiscus or [butterfly pea](https://vivavn.com/how-to-make-butterfly-pea-tea/) – for a soothing experience.
You can find dried passion fruit from Vietnam online — **[this option on Amazon](https://amzn.to/3I2sKH3)** is a good place to start.
_Watch our video on passion fruit._
## Dried rambutan
_The translucent white flesh of rambutan is the ingredient used to make dried rambutan._
_Freeze-dried rambutan fruits_
**Taste:** Naturally sweet with a slight tang.
**Texture:** Light, crisp, and slightly airy; breaks apart easily and melts on the tongue.
**How to enjoy:** As a snack, as a smoothie topping.
[Rambutan](https://vivavn.com/rambutan/) is a juicy, sweet tropical fruit with a spiky red shell and translucent flesh that’s full of flavor. Through freeze-drying, it’s transformed into [dried rambutan](https://vivavn.com/dried-rambutan/) — a light, crunchy snack, similar in texture to dried dragon fruit. Each bite melts in the mouth with a pleasant sweetness and a gentle tang, making it hard to stop at just one piece.  

Dried rambutan isn’t always easy to find, but **[this version on Amazon](https://amzn.to/3GGtj99)** captures the texture and flavor well.
## Dried mango
_Ripe mango with golden flesh is the ingredient used to make dried mango._
_Chewy slices of Vietnamese dried mango_
**Taste:** Sweet with a gentle tangy edge.
**Texture:** Chewy and flexible, with a satisfying bite.
**How to enjoy:** As a snack, blended into smoothies, or added to salads.
[Dried mango](https://vivavn.com/vietnam-dried-mango/) is made from ripe, juicy mangoes known for their natural sweetness and fragrant aroma. Fresh slices are slowly dried at low temperatures — typically between 50–60°C (122–140°F) — over several hours. This process removes moisture while preserving the fruit’s bright color, soft chewiness, and concentrated flavor.
Some producers may add sugar during the drying process of mango to enhance its sweetness, so it’s a good idea to check the label if you’re looking for an unsweetened option.
_Watch our video on dried mango._
## Dried jackfruit
_Crispy Vietnamese dried jackfruit slices_
**Taste:** Naturally sweet with a rich tropical aroma.
**Texture:** Light and crispy.
**How to enjoy:** Enjoy it as a snack, or add to smoothies, yogurt, or oatmeal.
Jackfruit is known for its sweet aroma and chewy, stringy texture when ripe. Through freeze-drying, it transforms into a light, crispy chip while retaining its natural fragrance and sweetness. The result is a crunchy snack that captures the essence of fresh jackfruit in every bite.
A quality freeze-dried version is available [**here on Amazon**](https://amzn.to/3TC5YZi) if you’d like to experience it for yourself.
## Dried banana chips
_Crispy dried banana chips from Vietnam_
**Taste:** Sweet with no tartness.
**Texture:** crunchy.
**How to enjoy:** Enjoy as a snack, or add to cereal and yogurt bowls.
Made from naturally ripe bananas, these chips deliver pure banana flavor—sweet, mellow, and familiar. Unlike soft-dried varieties, [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam) banana chips are thinly sliced and fried or dried until golden and crisp. The process gives them a satisfying crunch while locking in their natural sweetness.
## Frequently asked questions about dried dragon fruit
### Are these dried fruits sweetened?
Most of the fruits featured in this list are naturally sweet and don’t contain added sugar. Always check the product label if you’re buying online—some brands may add sweeteners or oil for texture.
### What’s the difference between freeze-dried and soft-dried fruit?
Freeze-dried fruits are light, airy, and crunchy, while soft-dried fruits are chewy and moist. Freeze-drying removes more moisture and usually retains more of the fruit’s original shape and color.
### Can I use dried fruits in recipes?
Absolutely. Dried fruits can be added to oatmeal, salads, yogurt bowls, smoothies, baked goods, or even savory dishes.
### Where can I buy authentic Vietnamese dried fruits?
You can find many options on Amazon or specialty Asian markets. In this post, we’ve included affiliate links to trusted products that are worth trying.
### How should I store dried fruits to keep them fresh?
Keep dried fruits in an airtight container in a cool, dry place. For longer storage, especially in humid climates, refrigeration or freezing helps preserve texture and flavor.

# Vietnamese Longan: All You Need to Know About This Fruit
We’re excited to share some valuable insights about the Vietnamese longan.
7 min
[](https://vivavn.com/fruit/)
Fruit
[](https://youtu.be/BRioON73wLQ)
_In this article, we’ll explore Vietnamese longans, or “nhãn”. Discover their unique shape, sweet flavor, and their traditional uses in Vietnamese medicine. Learn how to enjoy and store them, differentiate them from lychees, and uncover their nutritional benefits. We’ll also highlight the top longan-growing regions in Vietnam. Whether you’re a fruit lover or just curious, this article will give you a taste of the world of Vietnamese longans!_
## What is Vietnamese longan?
**Overview**
**Vietnamese name:** nhãn or long nhãn
**Shape and appearance:** round, with thin, brown, leathery skin and a translucent, white interior. The fruit contains a single, dark brown seed.
**Flavor profile:** sweet, and musky, with a juicy texture.
**How to enjoy it:** eat fresh, add to fruit salads, use in desserts, or make longan syrup and drinks.
**Harvest season:** The longan harvest season in Vietnam usually runs from July to October.
### Shape and color
Longan fruits are round, measuring 2 to 3 cm in diameter. They grow in clusters, with each cluster containing 10 to 20 fruits. The fruits have thin, brown, leathery skin and a translucent, white flesh that encases a single dark brown seed.
Depending on the variety, longan trees vary in height. In northern Vietnam, they typically reach 10 to 15 meters, while in southern Vietnam, they grow to about 6 to 7 meters. In Vietnam, longan trees usually flower in May, with the fruit season lasting from July to October.
The longan tree is in bloom
Vietnamese longan trees
### Taste and flavor
Longans are sweet and tender, with a juicy texture and just a bit of crispness. After eating, you’ll notice a subtle musky aftertaste that lingers on your tongue. When you peel the fruit, it releases a gentle and pleasant aroma.
### Longan vs lychee
Some of you may get confused between longan and lychee. To help clear up the confusion, we’ve put together a comparison of the two fruits. With key differences in appearance, texture, and taste, you’ll no longer struggle to tell longan and lychee apart!
### Longan
**Shape and appearance** : round shape and thin, brown, leathery skin.
**Texture** : Longan has flesh that is thinner and slightly crispier than lychee’s.
**Taste:** Longan has a sweet, and musky flavor.
### Lychee
**Shape and appearance** : round or heart-shaped with a rough, pink or red rind.
**Texture:** The texture of lychee is soft, juicy, and similar to jelly.
**Taste:** Lychee has a sweet, a bit of a sour taste, and a perfumed flavor.
## How to eat Vietnamese longan
The skin of a longan is thin and easy to peel. Simply use your thumbs to gently remove the outer layer, or make a light cut with a knife to peel it off.
After peeling, you can pop the longan into your mouth and use your teeth to separate the flesh from the seed—just don’t chew or swallow the seed. Alternatively, you can use your fingers to remove the flesh from the seed and then enjoy the fruit.
## Nutritional facts of Longan
Here’s the nutritional breakdown for a 3.5-ounce (100-gram) serving of longan, based on data from the **[USDA](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/169089/nutrients)** :
**Nutrient** | **Amount**  
---|---  
**Vitamin C** | 84 mg  
**Potassium (K)** | 266 mg  
**Energy** | 60 kcal  
**Carbohydrate, by difference** | 15.1 g  
**Fiber** | 1.1 g  
**Protein** | 1.31 g  
**Total lipid (fat)** | 0.1 g  
**Magnesium (Mg)** | 10 mg  
**Iron (Fe)** | 0.13 mg  
**Sodium (Na)** | 0 mg  
## How to pick delicious Vietnamese longan fruits
When choosing longan, look for bunches that come with stems. The fruit should have a shiny, firm skin and vibrant color, with fresh leaves that emit a pleasant aroma. Avoid fruits that are leaking juice, mushy, damp, have cracked skins, or show dark spots.
To test for ripeness, gently squeeze the longan with your fingers. If it feels slightly soft but not too firm, it’s a sign that the fruit is juicy and ripe.
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/)
#### **[Vietnamese Fruits: The Best Varieties to Try in Vietnam](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/)**
_We’ve put together the ultimate list of Vietnam’s best fruits just for you. To make it even more fun, take our quiz and see how well you know your Vietnamese fruits. Plus, don’t miss our handy PDF guide packed with all the details about these amazing fruits! [**[Read](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/)**]_
## How to store Vietnamese longan fruits
Longans are a deliciously sweet and juicy fruit that can be enjoyed on their own or as part of a refreshing dessert. To make the most of their flavor and extend their shelf life, it’s important to store them properly. If you’ve just picked up a fresh batch from the market, follow these simple steps to keep your longans fresh and tasty for days to come.
**Step 1:** Give the longans a good rinse under cool running water, then gently snip them off the branches. Set them aside to air dry.
**Step 2:** Carefully inspect the longans, discarding any that are bruised, overly soft, or show signs of mold or pests. 
**Step 3:** Transfer the longans to vented plastic bags to keep them fresh, then pop them into the crisper drawer of your fridge. They’ll stay juicy and delicious for longer this way.
## The uses of longan in traditional Vietnamese medicine
Image credit: Long Nhãn Sấy Khô Hưng Yên
In traditional Vietnamese medicine, longans are preserved by drying the fruit. After drying, they develop a rich yellow or dark brown color. The dried longans become soft and chewy, with a sweet flavor and a subtle, distinctive aroma. They can be used alone or combined with other herbs to create remedies for various conditions, such as boosting energy, improving memory, and combating skin aging.
These are the uses according to traditional Vietnamese medicine, and no scientific research has yet confirmed or disproved them.
## Traditional Vietnamese recipes with longan
### 1. Vietnamese longan and lotus seed sweet soup
**Ingredients:**
Fresh lotus seeds
Fresh longans
Rock sugar
Water
Ice cubes (for serving chilled)
**Here’s how it’s made:**
Start by boiling the fresh lotus seeds until tender, then drain and set them aside. Next, carefully peel the longans, making sure to remove the seeds while keeping the fruit whole. Gently stuff each lotus seed into the hollowed-out longans.
In a pot, dissolve the rock sugar in water and bring it to a simmer. Add the stuffed longans and let them cook briefly—just enough for them to soak up the sweet syrup. Remove the pot from heat and let the soup cool to room temperature. For a refreshing finish, chill the soup in the refrigerator.
When you’re ready to serve, ladle the soup into bowls, garnishing with extra lotus seeds and ice cubes. This dessert is light, refreshing, and perfect for a warm day!
### 2. Longan tea
**Ingredients:**
Fresh longans
Jasmine tea bags
Rock sugar
Granulated sugar
Water, ice cubes, and salt
**Here’s how it’s made:**
**Prepare the Longans:** Peel the longans, remove the seeds, and rinse the fruit with warm water. Sweeten the longan flesh with granulated sugar and let it sit for about 15 to 20 minutes.
**Cook the Longan Syrup:** In a pot, bring water to a boil with rock sugar and a pinch of salt. Once the sugar and salt have dissolved, add the sweetened longan flesh and cook until the longans turn opaque and the syrup thickens. Then remove from heat.
**Brew the Tea:** Steep the jasmine tea bags in hot water for about 5 to 8 minutes.
**Mix the Drink:** Combine some jasmine tea with a portion of the longan syrup and a few ice cubes. Stir well, pour into a glass, and enjoy!
## Which areas in Vietnam are known for growing longans?
The famous 400-year-old longan tree in Hung Yen Province, Vietnam (Credit: Ngọc-Bình/ www. cand.com.vn)
In Vietnam, longan trees thrive across various regions, with the largest cultivation areas found in the Mekong Delta and northern parts of the country. However, the most famous longan-growing area is Hung Yen Province, known for its exceptional “Hung Yen Longan (nhãn lồng Hưng Yên)”. This variety is renowned for its large size, juicy, thick pulp, sweet flavor, and delightful aroma. Historically, Hung Yen Longan was so prized that it was chosen as a royal offering to the king each year.
**Did you know?** In Hung Yen, you’ll find the oldest longan tree in the area, a remarkable 400 years old. This historic tree is believed to be the first longan tree ever planted in the region. Locals have built a shrine and protective structure around it to honor and preserve this living piece of their heritage.

# Vietnamese Coconut Nectar: Sokfarm’s Sustainable Sweetener
Introducing Vietnamese coconut nectar and the famous Sokfarm brand that produces organic coconut nectar.
8 min
[](https://vivavn.com/organic-products/)
Organic products
[](https://vivavn.com/coconut/)
Coconut
## Introduction
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
Coconut nectar is the purest product of [the coconut tree](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut/), collected from the unopened coconut flower buds, which contain a high concentration of nutrients that nourish all parts of the coconut fruit.
Vietnamese coconut nectar is gaining popularity worldwide as an organic product that not only tastes delicious but also offers health benefits. It is rich in nutrients and minerals, including potassium, magnesium, iron, and zinc.
The harvesting and processing of coconut nectar are traditionally carried out by the Khmer people in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam’s largest coconut-growing region.
## The allure of Sokfarm coconut nectar
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
Vietnamese brand, Sokfarm, stands out as a pioneer in organic coconut nectar production. Their commitment to sustainability extends from organically cultivating coconut trees to responsible nectar collection, ensuring the well-being of the environment and ecosystem.
###  Unique flavor
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
Sokfarm coconut nectar has a unique flavor profile that is characterized by its sweetness, mineral notes, and slightly sour aftertaste.
The sweetness of Vietnamese coconut nectar is unique, offering a delicate flavor derived from coconut flowers. The high concentration of minerals in the nectar, such as potassium, magnesium, and iron, not only enhances its overall flavor but also provides numerous health benefits.
The slightly sour aftertaste of Vietnamese coconut nectar is due to the natural fermentation process that takes place after the nectar is collected. This fermentation process gives the nectar a unique flavor that is both sweet and sour.
### A natural source of vitamins and minerals
Sokfarm fresh coconut nectar is rich in important minerals such as iron, zinc, calcium, kali, natri, and potassium, as well as other nutrients such as 17 amino acids. These ingredients provide energy, electrolytes, and support the body during exercise and recovery.
Sokfarm Organic Coconut Nectar has a low glycemic index (GI) of 55, compared to refined sugar which has a GI of around 85 and honey which has an average GI of 60. A low GI is ideal for those looking to stabilize their blood sugar levels.
### Purely organic
Fresh coconut nectar serves as a natural and organic sweetener, free from additives and artificial ingredients. Sokfarm is dedicated to the sustainable production of coconut nectar. Collaborating with local coconut farmers, the company imparts organic farming techniques and traditional [Khmer ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khmer_people)methods for collecting nectar from coconut flowers.
## Sokfarm’s commitment to sustainable harvesting: the secret behind their delicious nectar
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
### 1. Choosing the perfect tree:
Coconut trees have to be at least 3 years old and consistently producing fruit before they’re ready for nectar collection. This ensures the tree is mature and healthy. Each tree contributes for 9 months, followed by a 3-month rest period to recover.
### 2. Waking up the flowers
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
Skilled harvesters climb the trees to find unopened coconut flowers. They gently massage the flowers to stimulate nectar production. Then, using a wooden pestle, they carefully tap the flowers to encourage even more nectar flow. Experienced harvesters know exactly how much pressure to apply – too much can damage the flower, while too little won’t stimulate enough nectar.
### 3. Collecting the liquid gold
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
Once the flowers are prepared, the harvester uses a small knife to make a precise cut at the tip, allowing the nectar to drip out. A special container collects the precious liquid as it flows from the flower.
### 4. From blossom to bottle
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
After harvesting, the fresh coconut nectar is transported to Sokfarm’s facilities. Here, it’s transformed into a variety of delicious and versatile products, including fermented coconut nectar, concentrated nectar, coconut sugar, and even coconut nectar-infused soy sauce and vinegar.
## How a couple revived a community with Sokfarm
Image: Sokfarm – Tra Vinh Organic Coconut Nectar
Chal Thi grew up in a small village in Tra Vinh Province, Vietnam, surrounded by coconut trees. She loved coconuts and dreamed of doing something to improve the lives of coconut farmers in her community.
After graduating from college with a degree in food technology, Chal Thi got a stable job in Ho Chi Minh City. In 2018, Chal Thi heard from her father that the price of coconuts had plummeted. Farmers were struggling to make a living. Chal Thi decided to quit her job and return to her hometown to help.
She and her husband, Pham Dinh Ngai, an electrical engineer who shared her passion for coconuts. Together, they decided to start a business producing coconut nectar, a traditional Khmer product.
At first, they faced many challenges. They failed repeatedly and were met with skepticism from local farmers. But Chal Thi and Ngai were determined to succeed.
They learned the traditional methods of collecting coconut nectar from the village elders. They experimented with different processing techniques and eventually developed a high-quality product.
In 2019, Chal Thi and Ngai launched their company, Sokfarm. Today, they sell their products to customers all over Vietnam and are even exporting to other countries.
Sokfarm provides a stable income for hundreds of local coconut farmers. Over 70% of the company’s workforce are women. The company has developed over 20 hectares of organic coconut farms.
In July 2023, Sokfarm’s coconut nectar was awarded a 5-star OCOP certification by the Vietnamese government. This is the highest rating possible under the [OCOP ](https://vivavn.com/what-is-ocop-vietnam/)program. Sokfarm was also one of 30 businesses in Vietnam recognized in 2023 for its outstanding social impact and climate-resilient farming methods.
### Aspiration for sustainable agriculture
Tra Vinh, a province located in the Mekong Delta region, faces a grim outlook. Scientists predict that within the next 30-50 years, climate change will cause approximately 30% of the area to be submerged or infiltrated by saline water, rendering many crops unable to thrive.
However, coconut trees stand out as resilient to saline inundation, though their productivity and quality will inevitably suffer. In response to this challenge, Sokfarm has transitioned to a coconut farming model centered around harvesting coconut flower nectar. This innovative approach not only ensures the sustainability of farming practices but also significantly boosts farmers’ income by 3-5 times.
Sokfarm employs the traditional method of the Khmer people to harvest coconut flower nectar. This contributes to the preservation of the traditional industry for the local community.
In addition, coconut gardens that produce coconut nectar also provide eco-tourism opportunities for visitors from around the world to witness firsthand how locals produce organic coconut nectar. The couple aims to promote sustainable agriculture, partnering with local farmers to introduce coconut nectar products to a global market.

# Vietnamese Starfruit: All You Need to Know About This Fruit
We’re excited to share some valuable insights about the Vietnamese starfruit.
6 min
[](https://vivavn.com/fruit/)
Fruit
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V5YGRfu5j-o)
_In this article, we’re about to unlock the secrets of Vietnamese starfruit, a fruit that’s as intriguing as it is delicious. We’ll explore its distinctive shape and tangy flavor, share tips on how to enjoy it and guide you in selecting the perfect, ripe starfruit. You’ll also discover how starfruit is used in Vietnamese cuisine. Plus, we’ll tell you a beloved Vietnamese folktale about the starfruit tree, a story every child in Vietnam grows up hearing. And to test your newfound knowledge, we’ve included some fun trivia questions about this fascinating fruit! Whether you’re a food lover or just curious about Vietnamese culture, there’s something here for you!_
## What is Vietnamese star fruit?
**Overview**
**Vietnamese name:** khế
**Shape and appearance:** Starfruit has a star-shaped cross-section when sliced, with smooth, shiny skin ranging from green to yellow. It is crisp and juicy with some seeds inside.
**Flavor profile:** Sweet with a hint of tanginess, and a refreshing, slightly citrusy taste.
**How to enjoy it:** Eat fresh, slice it into star shapes, or blend it into smoothies.
**Harvest season:** Available year-round, with peak season from late summer to late autumn.
### Shape and color
Vietnamese starfruit, or khế, has a distinctive shape with a length ranging from 5 to 15 cm. When sliced crosswise, it reveals a star-like pattern, which is how it got its name. The **[fruit](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/)** grows in clusters and starts green, turning yellow as it ripens. Inside, you’ll find small, brown seeds located in the center.
Starfruit trees typically reach a height of 3 to 6 meters and have lush, dense foliage with pretty clusters of purple flowers. They bear fruit year-round, adding a touch of vibrant color to gardens throughout the seasons.
The beauty of starfruit blossom
A starfruit tree in a Vietnamese home garden.
### Taste and flavor
In **[Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam)** , there are two main types of starfruit: the sweet variety and the sour variety.
The sweet starfruit has a mild flavor with a hint of tartness. It is usually low in sugar content (around 4%), giving it a gentle, not overly sweet taste. When ripe, the sweet starfruit is juicy, with a crisp texture similar to grapes, and has a light, refreshing flavor.
On the other hand, the sour starfruit has a sharper, tangier taste, similar to that of green apples. When unripe, it is firm and has a distinct sourness. This type of starfruit is often used in cooking to add a zesty, tangy flavor to dishes.
## How to eat the star fruit
To enjoy starfruit, follow these simple steps:
**Wash the Fruit** : Rinse the starfruit under cold water to remove any dirt or residues.
**Slice the Fruit** : Use a sharp knife to cut the starfruit crosswise into slices. Each slice will have a star shape.
**Eat Fresh** : You can eat the slices directly as a fresh snack. The skin is edible and has a mild flavor.
**Remove Seeds (Optional)** : While the seeds are edible, you might prefer to remove them for a smoother eating experience.
**Try in Recipes** : Starfruit can also be used in salads, salsas, or as a garnish for various dishes.
## How to choose a ripe starfruit
To select a ripe starfruit, look for one that is mostly yellow with a hint of light green. The skin should be slightly waxy, and the edges will have brown ridges. The fruit should feel firm to the touch.
Avoid starfruit that is overly yellow with brown spots, as this indicates that it may be overripe and could taste bland and have a soggier texture. Remember, if the starfruit is still slightly green, it can ripen at room temperature, but its sweetness won’t increase.
## Starfruit in Vietnamese cuisine
The Vietnamese starfruit soup with beef, or ‘Canh Khế Thịt Bò,’ offers a tangy and savory flavor profile. The starfruit brings a refreshing tartness that complements the rich taste of tender beef. This combination is elevated by the fragrant aroma of green onions and shallots, along with the depth added by traditional Vietnamese seasonings like fish sauce and black pepper. The result is a harmonious balance of tangy, savory, and aromatic elements that is both comforting and invigorating.
## A Vietnamese folktale about starfruit
In elementary school, Vietnamese students often learn about a folktale involving the starfruit tree through their textbooks.
Illustration of the Vietnamese starfruit folktale from a school textbook (Source: voh.com.vn)
In the Vietnamese folktale “The Starfruit Tree,” two brothers inherit their family’s estate after their parents pass away. The elder brother, who is lazy and selfish, convinces the younger brother to take only a small run-down hut and a starfruit tree while he keeps the larger portion of their inheritance. The younger brother and his wife work tirelessly, cultivating their land and taking care of the starfruit tree, which grows lush and bears many fruits.
One day, a giant bird arrives and starts eating the ripe starfruits. The couple, relying on the fruits for their livelihood, kindly ask the bird to stop. To their surprise, the bird speaks, promising to repay them with gold if they sew a small bag. Following the bird’s instructions, the younger brother makes a bag measuring exactly three hand spans and waits. The bird returns, carrying the younger brother on its back to a faraway island filled with precious gems and gold. He takes only enough gold to fill his small bag and returns home, now able to live comfortably but modestly.
When the elder brother learns of this, his jealousy is sparked. He convinces his younger brother to trade their small hut and the starfruit tree for his larger estate. The greedy elder brother and his wife eagerly wait for the bird. When the bird arrives and repeats the same offer, the elder brother sews a much larger bag, three times the size of the one his brother had made.
The bird, unaware of the deception, takes the elder brother to the treasure island. Greed takes over, and he stuffs the bag with as much gold and gems as he can carry, even filling his clothes. The bird struggles to fly back because of the heavy load, and eventually, over the ocean, it can no longer carry the weight. The elder brother is thrown into the sea, where he drowns, weighed down by his greed.
The story teaches a timeless lesson: those who are humble, honest, and hardworking will find true prosperity, while greed and selfishness ultimately lead to downfall.

# Cam Thanh Coconut Village: Your Ultimate Guide to a Unique Hoi An Experience+ Videos
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/countryside/)
Countryside
[](https://youtu.be/eNut1ASJV98)
_In this article, we’ll take you on a journey to explore the unique charm of the Cam Thanh Coconut Village in Hoi An. You’ll discover what makes this hidden gem so special, learn about the unforgettable experiences waiting for you, and get tips on the best ways to get there. Plus, we’ve included all the details on ticket prices and transportation options, so you’re fully prepared for your visit. Whether you’re a nature lover or just looking for something off the beaten path, this guide has everything you need to make the most of your trip!_
What makes Cam Thanh Village special?
Experiences in Cam Thanh
Directions & transport
Entrance fee
## What makes Cam Thanh Coconut Village special?
To start, we’d like to show you what sets the Cam Thanh Coconut Village apart from other [villages in Hoi An](https://vivavn.com/hoi-an-villages/). And just to clear up any confusion—Cam Thanh Water Coconut Forest, Bay Mau Coconut Forest, and Hoi An Coconut Forest are all different names for the same place.
### The vast, pristine water coconut forest
This charming village is nestled right next to Cua Dai Beach, covering an area of 900 hectares, with nearly half of that being water. The village is known for its network of winding rivers and a unique mangrove ecosystem, where water coconut trees thrive and provide a habitat for many fish species. The lush waterways and vibrant coconut forests are part of what makes this area so captivating for visitors exploring this region
### The peaceful countryside landscape of Hội An’s river region
Although it’s just a short distance away from the beautiful [Tra Que Vegetable Village](https://vivavn.com/tra-que-vegetable-village/) (about 5 kilometers), the countryside here offers a different charm. While Tra Que is known for its homes nestled among gardens of fresh herbs and vegetables, Cam Thanh greets you with delightful little houses that line the riverbanks, hidden behind rows of swaying coconut palms. Strolling through the villages of Cam Thanh, you can truly feel the peaceful and refreshing atmosphere that makes this place so special.
Two hundred years ago, there were no water coconut trees in Cam Thanh. The locals brought these trees from the southwestern region of Vietnam and planted them here. Thanks to the favorable soil and climate, the water coconuts thrived, and today, the village boasts around 300 hectares of these lush palms.
## What exciting experiences await you in Cam Thanh coconut village?
Compared to other countryside areas in Hoi An, the experience at the Cam Thanh water coconut forest revolves primarily around the water. To fully appreciate the beauty of this region, you’ll want to hop on a local basket boat, known as a thúng, and explore the landscapes. Along the way, you can enjoy fun activities.
### Ride in a basket boat
When you visit this village, one experience you definitely shouldn’t miss is riding in a basket boat. Each boat can hold up to four people, and a skilled local will guide you through the beautiful water coconut forests. You’ll be thrilled as they show off their amazing rowing skills with a performance known as ‘boat dancing.’ Plus, you’ll get to watch local fishermen expertly casting their nets.
### Create adorable handmade crafts using water coconut leaves
You might not know this, but the locals here make the most of water coconut leaves. They use them for thatching roofs, as firewood, and even to create beautiful handmade crafts. The residents will happily show you how to transform these leaves into charming items like bracelets, rings, sunglasses, and adorable little animals.
### Learn how to cook traditional Vietnamese dishes
All the restaurants in the village offer cooking classes for visitors. If you’re interested, you can sign up for a class to learn how to make traditional Vietnamese dishes like [Mì Quảng](https://vivavn.com/mi-quang-quang-noodles/), [Bánh Xèo](https://vivavn.com/banh-xeo-vietnamese-pancakes/), or a hearty Vietnamese meal using fresh, local ingredients.
## How to get to Cam Thanh Coconut Village from Hoi An Ancient Town
### Directions
Just 5 kilometers southeast of Hoi An’s Ancient Town, once you leave the old town, you have three routes to take you to the Cam Thanh Coconut Village. We recommend taking the route through Tran Nhan Tong, Nguyen Duy Hieu, and Tong Van Suong streets. Not only is this the shortest path, but you’ll also pass through a beautiful rice field along the way
### Transport
You can easily reach this village by taxi, Grab, motorbike, bicycle, or even on foot. We think the most enjoyable way to get here is by biking. As you ride, you’ll get to soak in the peaceful countryside scenery, complete with lush rice fields, grazing buffalo, and hardworking farmers going about their daily tasks.
## Is there an entrance fee for Cam Thanh Coconut Village?
Admission to the Cam Thanh Coconut Village is just 30,000 VND for adults and 15,000 VND for kids between 1 and 1.3 meters tall. Children under 1 meter can enter for free! This ticket allows you to explore the beautiful scenery of the village, but if you want to take a ride in a basket boat and join in on some fun river activities, you’ll need to purchase an additional ticket for around 150,000 VND. If you’re interested in taking cooking classes, just reach out to the local restaurants for pricing information.

# What is Glutinous Rice?
Which Vietnamese Dishes Are Made from Glutinous Rice?
2 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
Discover
[](https://vivavn.com/category/rice/)
Rice
_Sticky rice is a type of rice grown mainly in Southeast Asia, East Asia and Northeast South Asia. The grains are opaque and especially sticky when cooked. In this article, let’s explore Vietnamese dishes made from glutinous rice._
## Banh Chung (Chung cake)
[Chung cake (Banh Chung)](https://vivavn.com/chung-cake/) holds a rich tradition in Vietnamese culture, spanning thousands of years. It stands as an essential delicacy, particularly during the Tet festival (Lunar new year) in Vietnam. The ingredients used to craft chung cake encompass glutinous rice, mung beans, pork, and Dong leaves. Making chung cake demands a considerable amount of time and effort. The process extends throughout the entire day, with preparations starting the day before.
## Xoi (sticky rice)
Sticky rice (Xoi) is a traditional dish that is indispensable during festive occasions and [Tet (Lunar new year)](https://vivavn.com/what-is-tet/). On these occasions, Vietnamese people offer sticky rice on the altar to express gratitude from descendants to their ancestors, as well as appreciation towards heaven and earth for providing a season of abundant harvests with favorable weather.
## Sweet soup
For Vietnamese people, a simple and delicious dish made from glutinous rice is glutinous rice sweet soup. To make this dish, we’ll need glutinous rice, sugar, and ginger. Begin by washing the glutinous rice and soaking it in water for about 3 hours to soften the grains. In a pot, mix sugar with water and bring it to a boil. Add the soaked glutinous rice to the boiling mixture, stirring well. When serving, ladle the glutinous rice sweet soup into a bowl and sprinkle a bit of ginger on top.

# **What is Giay Cake (Banh Giay)?**
The significance of Giay cake in Vietnamese Tet.
3 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
Discover
_Banh Giay or Banh Day (Giay cake or Day cake), alongside[ banh Chung](https://vivavn.com/chung-cake/) (Chung cake), holds a significant place as one of the essential traditional dishes during the Vietnamese Tet holiday. In this article, let’s explore banh giay and how to make this type of cake._
## The significance of Giay cake during Tet
According to official documents in Vietnam, “banh Giay” is the correct spelling. However, some Vietnamese people often write this type of cake as “banh Day”.
In Vietnamese folklore, Giay cake, with its round shape, is seen as a representation of the sky. This cake, white in color and fitting neatly in the palm of one’s hand, features a curved top that resembles the sky. In ancient Vietnamese culture, the sky was thought to be the dwelling place of divine beings. Therefore, Giay cake is often employed in rituals to honor the sky and to seek favorable weather for a prosperous and abundant year.
The legend recounts that [Chung cake ](https://vivavn.com/chung-cake/)and Giay cake have their roots in the time of the Sixth Hung King. It is said that after successfully defeating the An invaders, during the first days of the new year, the King aimed to pass the throne to one of his princes.
To determine the successor, the King gathered his sons and declared that the one who presented a delicious dish with significance to their ancestors would inherit the throne. The princes eagerly sought various rare and precious ingredients to offer their father. Among them, only Prince Lang Lieu, the eighteenth prince, kind and dutiful but without a mother for a long time, was uncertain about his choice.
One night, Lang Lieu dreamt of a deity guiding him: ‘Nothing in the world is as precious as rice grains, the sustenance of human life. Mold rice into round and square shapes, symbolizing Earth and Heaven. Wrap them with leaves and place the filling inside to symbolize the grace of childbirth from parents.’ When Lang Lieu presented the dish to the King, he was delighted to discover the tasty and meaningful Chung cake and Giay cake. Consequently, the King passed the throne to Lang Liêu. The origin of Chung cake and Giay cake can be traced back to this legend.
## Ingredients and making process
### Key components of Giay cake
[Glutinous rice](https://vivavn.com/what-is-glutinous-rice/)
Mung beans
Cooking oil
Banana leaves
### How Vietnamese people make Giay cake
#### Step 1: Preliminarily prepare glutinous rice
Wash the Dong leaves thoroughly with water.
After soaking for the required time, place the glutinous rice in a basket, allow it to drain.
#### Step 2: Preliminarily prepare mung beans
Wash the mung beans with water, then soak them in water for about 30 minutes.
After soaking for the required time, place the mung beans in a basket, allow it to drain.
#### Step 3: Mash the glutinous rice
Place the soaked glutinous rice into the pot and cook it. After approximately 10 minutes, uncover the pot and sprinkle some cooking oil over the glutinous rice. Then, continue cooking until the rice is fully cooked, soft, and sticky.
Transfer the cooked glutinous rice into a mortar, then use a pestle to pound it until it becomes smooth and forms into a cohesive block.
#### Step 4: Make the mung bean filling.
Place the washed mung beans into a pot and stir-fry.
Place the mung beans onto a plate and shape them into round balls. Chefs commonly apply cooking oil to their hands to prevent the mung beans from sticking.
#### Step 5: Make Giay cake
Flatten the glutinous rice into flat round shapes, then place a mung bean ball in the center. Next, wrap the mung bean ball with the glutinous rice. 
Once the cakes are finished, place them on banana leaves.

# Dried Rambutan: What It Tastes Like and Where to Find It
4 min
[](https://vivavn.com/dried-fruit/)

_Rambutan isn’t just a fun-looking tropical fruit; it also makes for a delicious dried snack. In this post, we’ll explore how dried rambutan is made, what it tastes like, and how it compares to other dried fruits like mango and dragon fruit. You’ll also find tips on how to enjoy it and where to buy a quality freeze-dried version online._

## What is dried rambutan?
Dried rambutan is a tropical fruit snack made by removing moisture from fresh rambutan using a freeze-drying process. In this method, the fruit is first frozen, and then the moisture is removed in a vacuum chamber by turning ice directly into vapor—a process known as [sublimation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublimation_\(phase_transition\)).
This technique helps the fruit maintain its natural shape, flavor, and nutrients. The result is a crisp, airy fruit snack that tastes sweet, floral, and slightly tangy—just like the fresh fruit, but in a convenient dried form.
**See fresh and freeze-dried rambutan in the two images below:**
The first image shows fresh rambutan with its red skin removed, revealing the juicy white flesh used in freeze-dried snacks.
The second image shows the freeze-dried version—light, crisp, and naturally sweet, with no added sugar.
_Fresh rambutan fruit_
_Freeze-dried rambutan_
## Taste and texture of dried rambutan
Dried rambutan has a naturally sweet and mildly floral flavor, similar to the fresh fruit but more concentrated. There’s also a hint of tanginess that balances the sweetness without being overpowering.
In terms of texture, freeze-dried rambutan is light, crisp, and slightly airy. It breaks apart easily in your mouth and melts gently on the tongue, similar to the texture of **[freeze-dried dragon fruit](https://vivavn.com/dried-dragon-fruit/)**.
Unlike chewy dried fruits like [**dehydrated mango**](https://vivavn.com/vietnam-dried-mango/) or [**passion fruit**](https://vivavn.com/passion-fruit/), which require more chewing, this version offers a delicate crunch that’s easy to eat.
To help you see the differences and similarities, here are three images below:
  1. **Freeze-dried rambutan** – crisp, airy, and light.
  2. **Freeze-dried dragon fruit** – with a similar melt-in-your-mouth texture.
  3. **Dehydrated mango** – chewy, flexible, and requires more bite.


_This freeze-dried rambutan is light, crisp, and naturally sweet._
_Freeze-dried dragon fruit slice showing the same airy texture as freeze-dried rambutan._
_Soft and chewy dried mango slices from Vietnam_
## How to enjoy dried rambutan
Dried rambutan is a convenient and versatile snack you can enjoy in many ways:
**On its own** : Enjoy straight from the bag for a quick, sweet, tropical bite.
**Topping for smoothie bowls:** Sprinkle freeze-dried rambutan over smoothie bowls to add crunch.
**With yogurt or granola:** Add some crisp rambutan pieces to your morning bowl for extra flavor and texture.
**Paired with tea:** Serve alongside a cup of herbal tea for a light, refreshing treat.
## Where to buy dried rambutan
Freeze-dried rambutan isn’t always easy to find in stores, but there are a few options available online. One product made in Vietnam uses freeze-drying to preserve the fruit’s natural flavor, shape, and texture, without added sugar or preservatives. You can find it _**[here on Amazon](https://amzn.to/3GGtj99)**_ (affiliate link)
## Frequently asked questions about dried rambutan
### What does dried rambutan taste like?
Dried rambutan has a naturally sweet, mildly floral flavor with a gentle tang. The freeze-drying process concentrates the taste, making it more intense than the fresh fruit but still well balanced.
### Is dried rambutan chewy or crunchy?
Freeze-dried rambutan is light, crisp, and slightly airy—it melts in your mouth, unlike chewy dried fruits like mango or passion fruit. It has a delicate crunch that’s easy to eat.
### How is dried rambutan made?
It’s made through a process called freeze-drying. The fruit is first frozen, then placed in a vacuum chamber where the ice turns directly into vapor (sublimation). This preserves the shape, flavor, and nutrients.
### How can I eat dried rambutan?
You can enjoy it on its own as a snack, sprinkle it over smoothie bowls, mix it into granola or yogurt, or pair it with tea. It’s a versatile and healthy option for both snacking and adding texture.
### What’s the difference between freeze-dried rambutan and dehydrated rambutan?
Freeze-dried rambutan is light and crispy, while dehydrated rambutan is chewy and denser.

# The Ultimate Guide to Exploring Tra Que Vegetable Village in Hoi An+ Videos
9 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/countryside/)
Countryside
[](https://youtu.be/eNut1ASJV98)
___Vietnam is a country where farming is a way of life, making agriculture a common sight in every village you visit. Just on the outskirts of Hoi An’s Ancient Town lies the famous Tra Que Vegetable Village, renowned for its lush fields and vibrant produce. It’s a must-visit spot for nearly every traveler exploring Hoi An. In this article, we’ll dive into what makes this village so captivating and provide you with a complete guide on how to experience it for yourself.___
[](https://vivavn.com/tra-que-vegetable-village/#title "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/tra-que-vegetable-village/#comment "Comment")
What makes Tra Que special?
Experiences in Tra Que
Daily sights in Tra Que
Tra Que weather
Directions & transport
Entrance fee
Attractions near Tra Que
## What makes Tra Que Vegetable Village so special?
Let’s take a deep dive into the fascinating history and unique flavors of the herbs and vegetables from Tra Que Village! We’ll uncover how the locals practice organic farming and why this charming village has captured the hearts of many.
### A 400-year legacy of traditional vegetable farming
About 400 years ago, the first Vietnamese settlers arrived in this area, mostly working as farmers and fishermen. As they prepared meals, they discovered that shrimp and fish cooked with the local vegetables had a unique, delicious flavor. That’s when the villagers decided to start collecting seeds and growing these vegetables themselves, kicking off Tra Que Village’s long-standing tradition of vegetable farming.
At first, the villagers simply grew vegetables to feed their families. But as they got better at farming, they expanded their land and started selling vegetables to their neighbors. Thanks to their delicious, unique flavor, Tra Que vegetables became famous throughout the region. Today, the descendants of those early settlers still carry on the tradition of keeping vegetable farming alive in Tra Que village.
### The vegetables and herbs here have unique flavors you won’t find anywhere else
Tra Que Village grows over 40 types of vegetables, fruits, and [herbs](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-herbs/)! Some of the most popular varieties include green onions, cilantro, [Vietnamese coriander](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coriander/), Thai basil, perilla, cilantro, and even [delicious fruits](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fruits/) like winter melon and papaya.
These plants are known for their small, thick leaves and compact stature, with many herbs boasting incredibly fragrant aromas. Locals in Hoi An often say that to truly enjoy their famous dishes like [Mì Quảng](https://vivavn.com/mi-quang-quang-noodles/) and Cao Lầu, you can’t skip the fresh greens from Tra Que Vegetable Village. They believe that these locally grown vegetables elevate the flavors.
The legend goes that the taste of the herbs and vegetables from Tra Que Village captivated the Nguyen king, leading him to rename the village after two of its plants.
In the 18th century, King Gia Long of the Nguyen Dynasty made a stop at the village. The villagers offered him the freshest and most delicious vegetables they had grown. Upon tasting them, the king was particularly impressed by a type of vegetable with a fragrant aroma like camellia and a spicy flavor reminiscent of cinnamon. After returning to the capital, he issued a decree changing the name of the village to Tra Que, which means “camellia and cinnamon” in Vietnamese.
### Farmers use organic methods to promote sustainability and protect the environment.
Farmers in Tra Que Vegetable Village grow their vegetables using traditional methods passed down through generations. When you visit, you’ll notice that their farming tools are quite simple and handmade. They cultivate native seeds that have thrived in this land for hundreds of years, perfectly suited to the local soil.
These farmers are very mindful of protecting their farmland, so they avoid using chemical fertilizers and pesticides. Instead, they use a unique fertilizer sourced from seaweed collected from a nearby lagoon. This seaweed is believed to contribute to the special flavor of the vegetables grown here.
## What exciting experiences await you in Tra Que Vegetable Village?
Over 20 years ago, Tra Que Vegetable Village opened its doors to tourists, inviting them to explore the art of vegetable farming in this beautiful area. Let’s dive into the authentic experiences this village offers when you visit!
### Enjoy the peaceful paths of Tra Que
Stroll along the quaint paths of the village, taking in the peaceful scenery and lush vegetable gardens, while watching the hardworking farmers tend to their crops. This experience offers a glimpse into how the Vietnamese approach farming.
**Here’s a fun fact:** the paths in Tra Que Vegetable Village are named after the local herbs and vegetables! You can stroll down Basil Street or Malabar Spinach Road, making your walk an experience filled with the flavors of the village!
### Planting, watering, and fertilizing the vegetables yourself
Not only can you observe, but you also get to roll up your sleeves and dive into the daily tasks of the local farmers. From tilling the soil and planting vegetables to watering the crops and adding fertilizer, these hands-on experiences give you a complete insight into how farming is done here.
**Tip:** The farmers here are incredibly friendly! Just ask, and they’ll happily guide you through the hands-on practices of farming.
### Learn how to cook traditional Vietnamese dishes
In Tra Que Vegetable Village, you can join cooking classes where experienced chefs teach you how to make traditional Vietnamese dishes like _[Banh Xeo](https://vivavn.com/banh-xeo-vietnamese-pancakes/)_ , _[Mi Quang](https://vivavn.com/mi-quang-quang-noodles/)_ , _[Nem Ran](https://vivavn.com/nem-ran-vietnamese-fried-spring-rolls/)_ , _Goi Cuon_ , and _Tam Huu_. Using fresh herbs and vegetables grown right here, it’s a fantastic way to learn how locals create these amazing flavors. Plus, you’ll get to taste the farm-fresh greens yourself, making it a truly authentic experience!
## What to see at different times of day
Farmers in Tra Que Vegetable Village start their day early, often heading to their fields by 5 AM to harvest vegetables to sell at the local markets. They work until around 11 AM before heading home for a break. By 3 PM, they’re back in the fields, continuing their work until about 5 PM.
These are the best times to catch the farmers in action and experience the bustling atmosphere of daily life. If you’re visiting the village, it’s worth coming during these hours to see the locals at work. Between 11 AM and 3 PM, the village tends to be quieter and less active.
**Tip:** Sunrise and sunset are the best times to enjoy the peaceful scenery of Tra Que village. If possible, try to visit during these times to fully appreciate the tranquility and beauty of the surroundings.
## The weather in Tra Que Vegetable Village
Hoi An enjoys a tropical monsoon climate, which means warm weather all year round, with average temperatures between 24 and 30 degrees Celsius. Let’s dive into the four distinct weather phases you can expect in both Hoi An and Tra Que.
The first three months are cool, with gentle sunshine and occasional showers.
From April to July, it’s the hottest time of the year, with temperatures reaching up to 36-37°C on some days.
August and September bring a transition period, with light sunshine, afternoon rain showers, and pleasant, cooler evenings.
While the last three months of the year are the rainy season, with occasional flooding in both Tra Que and nearby Hoi An, there are still many sunny days that are perfect for exploring the area.
## How to get to Tra Que Village from Hoi An Ancient Town
### Directions
Tra Que Vegetable Village is located about 4 km northeast of Hoi An Ancient Town. After you pass through the old town, you’ll stroll by a beautiful rice field before reaching the village. This rice field is a delightful stop you won’t want to miss! You can take a moment to watch the farmers at work or admire the water buffalo grazing nearby. Some locals even offer buffalo riding services—just pay a small fee, hop on, and snap some great photos!
**Note:** Tra Que Vegetable Village is divided into two parts, separated by Hai Ba Trung Street. If you’re coming from Hoi An Ancient Town, you’ll most likely enter the right side of the street. Don’t worry—you can explore the other part when you leave the village, just across the street!
### Transport
Getting from Hoi An Ancient Town to Tra Que Village is easy—you can choose to bike, ride a motorbike, take a taxi, use Grab, or even walk. But honestly, we recommend biking or walking for the best experience! You’ll find plenty of affordable bike rental shops in the old town.
**Tip:** Tra Que Herb Village is just about 1 km away from the beautiful An Bang Beach. After exploring the village, you can easily head towards the beach to enjoy the stunning coastal views!
## Is there an entrance fee for Tra Que Village?
The entrance fee to visit Tra Que Vegetable Village is 35,000 VND per person (around $1.50 USD) in 2024. After buying your ticket, you’ll get a free drink made with lemon basil seeds at a nearby restaurant. The seeds are harvested right from the gardens here.
With this ticket, you can explore Tra Que Village. If you’d like to join a cooking class, you’ll need to contact one of the restaurants in the village and pay an additional fee for the class.
## Awesome attractions near Tra Que Vegetable Village
### An Bang Beach
Just over 1 km from Tra Que Vegetable Village lies [An Bang Beach](https://vivavn.com/an-bang-beach/), a pristine beach with a peaceful vibe. With soft, white sand, gentle waves, and crystal-clear waters, it’s perfect for swimming and sunbathing. Plus, you’ll find plenty of nearby seafood restaurants serving fresh dishes!
### Cua Dai Beach
Not too long ago, Cua Dai Beach was a breathtaking paradise, but due to significant erosion, its size has shrunk and the landscape has changed. That said, if you visit today, you’ll still find its natural beauty intact, with a long stretch of soft white sand and palm trees lining the shore.
### Cam Thanh Coconut Village
[Cam Thanh Coconut Forest](https://vivavn.com/cam-thanh-coconut-village/), also known as Bay Mau Coconut Forest, is one of the unique [Hoi An Villages](https://vivavn.com/hoi-an-villages/). Just 8 km from Tra Que Vegetable Village, this area boasts a fascinating ecosystem of water coconut palms. When you visit, you can enjoy a basketboat ride on the river and take in the untouched natural beauty around you.
