# Vietnamese Artichoke Tea: Distinguishing the Two Types
[](https://vivavn.com/category/discover/)
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/tea/)
Tea
_In Vietnam, there are two[**types of tea**](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-tea/)called artichoke tea: green artichoke tea and red artichoke tea. They come from different plants and taste different._
## What’s the difference between green and red Vietnamese artichokes?
### Cynara Scolymus (green artichoke)
Cynara scolymus, also known as green artichoke in Vietnam, is a plant native to Southern Europe, particularly around the Mediterranean. Ancient Greeks and Romans cultivated it for its edible flowers. . The plant can grow up to 1.5 to 2 meters tall, and its leaves are 50–80 cm long.
In the early 20th century, French settlers brought this plant to Vietnam. Nowadays, it thrives in places like Da Lat in Lam Dong Province, Sapa in Lao Cai Province, and Tam Dao in [**Vinh Phuc**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V%C4%A9nh_Ph%C3%BAc_province) Province.
### Hibiscus Sabdariffa (red artichoke)
Hibiscus sabdariffa, also known as red artichoke in Vietnam, is a flowering plant native to Africa. It’s an annual plant that typically reaches heights of 1.5 to 2 meters, sporting strikingly bright red flowers atop light purple stems. Thriving in hot and humid climates, it’s resilient even in nutrient-poor soil conditions. Vietnam’s climate is perfect for growing Hibiscus sabdariffa, which is why you’ll see it all over the country.
**Note**
In Vietnam, Hibiscus sabdariffa is often called ‘red artichoke,’ but that can be confusing. It’s not actually related to artichokes (which are Cynara scolymus). Hibiscus sabdariffa is a different plant entirely.
## The colors and flavors of green artichoke tea and red artichoke tea
Green artichoke tea will exhibit a delicate golden yellow or light brown hue, while red artichoke tea features a vivid red reminiscent of cranberry juice.
The green artichoke tea has a naturally sweet and mild flavor. As for the red artichoke tea, it has a slightly tart taste, which becomes sweeter when mixed with sugar, and honey.
## How to make Vietnamese artichoke tea
We’ll show you how Vietnamese people make artichoke tea from both green and red artichoke flowers.
### Green artichoke tea
Green artichoke tea can be made from fresh or dried green artichoke flowers, or from green artichoke tea bags.
#### From fresh artichoke flowers
Vietnamese people wash fresh artichoke flowers, remove the old petals, cut the flowers in half or into quarters lengthwise, put them in a pot of water, and boil until the outer petals are easily pulled off. Then let it cool and scoop out the water to drink.
#### From dried artichoke flowers
Cut the artichoke in half and scoop out the fuzzy center (choke). Thinly slice the remaining artichoke and lay it flat to dry in the sun. This is how Vietnamese people traditionally make dried artichoke.
To brew dried artichoke tea, simply take a handful of dried artichoke and put it in a cup. Pour boiling water over it and let it steep for 5 to 10 minutes. Then, add honey and lemon juice to taste, stir, and enjoy!
#### From green artichoke tea bags
Image: Trà Cao Atiso Đà Lạt thương hiệu XUÂN VY
In Vietnam, artichoke tea bags are widely used because they’re convenient. Whenever we want to enjoy artichoke tea, we simply take 1 or 2 tea bags from the box, put them in a cup or teapot, pour boiling water over them, and wait 5-10 minutes. We can also add honey, lemon, ginger, or other ingredients to create different flavors.
### Red artichoke tea
Like green artichoke tea, red artichoke tea can be made using fresh or dried flowers.
#### From fresh red artichoke flowers
[**To make red artichoke tea**](https://vivavn.com/hibiscus-flowers-tea/), Vietnamese people start with 4-5 fresh red artichoke flowers. We wash the flowers with warm water, then add them to a pot of water. We might also add a few slices of ginger, sugar, or honey. We bring the mixture to a boil and simmer for 4-5 minutes. Finally, we pour the tea into a cup and enjoy!
[**How to Make Vietnamese Hibiscus Flower Tea**](https://vivavn.com/hibiscus-flowers-tea/)
#### From dried red artichoke flowers
Here’s how Vietnamese people traditionally prepare dried red artichoke flowers for tea: First, they carefully pick the best-looking flowers. Then, they remove the fuzzy center part, which is called the pistil. Next, they wash the flowers thoroughly to get rid of any dirt, bugs, or unwanted bits. Finally, the flowers are dried to become dried red artichoke tea.
To make dried red artichoke tea, Vietnamese people start with a cup of hot water. We add the red dried artichoke flowers to the water and let it steep for 5-10 minutes. Then, we might add a bit of honey or rock sugar to our cup, stir it up, and enjoy!
## Health benefits of green and red artichokes
### Health benefits of Cynara scolymus (green artichoke)
According to the Healthline website, Cynara scolymus offers a wealth of nutritional benefits. Low in fat and high in fiber, they are packed with essential vitamins and minerals such as vitamin C, folate, phosphorus, and magnesium. Additionally, they may contribute to improving cholesterol levels, regulating blood pressure, and enhancing liver health. Their fiber content supports digestive health and may alleviate symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome. Furthermore, this plant is rich in antioxidants and has been linked to lowering blood sugar levels and exhibiting potential anticancer effects.
[https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/artichoke-benefits](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/artichoke-benefits#TOC_TITLE_HDR_2)
### Health benefits of Hibiscus sabdariffa (red artichoke)
According to the Healthline website, Hibiscus sabdariffa is packed with antioxidants, making it a powerful addition to your wellness routine. Not only may it help lower blood pressure and improve blood fat levels, but it could also boost liver health and promote weight loss. Additionally, its compounds show potential in preventing cancer and inhibiting the growth of bacteria.
<https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/hibiscus-tea-benefits>
## Summary
In Vietnam, there are two types of tea known as artichoke tea: green artichoke tea and red artichoke tea. They originate from different plants.
Green artichoke tea is sourced from Cynara scolymus, while red artichoke tea is derived from Hibiscus sabdariffa.
Green artichoke tea and red artichoke tea are two different drinks with different colors and tastes.
Both green and red artichoke tea can be prepared from either fresh flowers or dried flowers.
Both green artichoke tea and red artichoke tea offer numerous health benefits.

# Nem Ran (Vietnamese Fried Spring Rolls)
3 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/cuisine)
Cuisine
[](https://youtu.be/eNut1ASJV98)
_In this article, we’ll introduce you to Vietnam’s famous fried spring rolls. Discover the key ingredients, learn how to make them, and find out the best ways to enjoy this delicious dish. Plus, we’ll explore the different names for this beloved treat in various regions of Vietnam._
Ingredients
How to make nem ran
How to enjoy nem ran
Different names for this dish
## Ingredients
**Filling:**
Ground pork
Eggs 
Carrots
Kohlrabi
Green onions
Wood ear mushrooms
Shiitake mushrooms
Onions
Black pepper
Glass noodles
Rice paper wrappers
**Fresh Herbs:**
Lettuce
Fish mint
Thai basil
Cucumbers
**Dipping Sauce:**
Fish sauce
Lime juice
Chilis
Garlic
Green papaya
Carrots
Sugar
## How to make nem ran
This overview provides a general guide to making Vietnamese fried spring rolls without diving into specific ingredient quantities.
Start by preparing the filling. Ground pork is mixed with finely chopped onion, kohlrabi, and carrots. Rehydrate wood ear and shiitake mushrooms, then chop them up. Soak dried glass noodles in warm water, drain, and cut them into smaller pieces. In a large bowl, combine all the ingredients with some cooking oil, seasoning, fish sauce, and an egg for richness.
Next, take a rice paper wrapper, add a portion of the filling, and roll it up tightly, tucking in the sides as you go. Finally, fry the spring rolls in hot oil until they turn golden brown and crispy.
## How to enjoy nem ran
Vietnamese people enjoy this dish with a dipping sauce. The sauce is made from a mixture of lime juice, fish sauce, water, and sugar, resulting in a balance of sour, spicy, salty, and sweet flavors. To enhance the taste, finely chopped chili, garlic, and small slices of carrot and green papaya are often added.
[The fresh herbs](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-herbs/) served with the dish typically include lettuce, basil, fish mint, and cucumber. When eating fried spring rolls, they are combined with these fresh herbs, dipped into [_nuoc cham_ (Vietnamese dipping sauce)](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-fish-sauce/), and enjoyed together.
## The different names for Vietnamese fried spring rolls
In Vietnam, fried spring rolls go by different names depending on the region. People in the North call them “nem rán,” while in the Central region, they’re known as “ram.” Down South, they’re referred to as “chả giò.” While the traditional filling often includes pork, some places get creative and use seafood like shrimp or crab instead.

# Japanese Covered Bridge in Hoi An: History, Architecture, and Travel Guide
6 min
Hoi An Town
[](https://youtu.be/oIk9LUfrjDo)
_The Japanese Covered Bridge, also known as Chua Cau, is the most iconic architectural landmark of Hoi An. Built over 400 years ago during the town’s prosperous trading era, it reflects a unique blend of Japanese, Chinese, and Vietnamese design. This complete guide will help you explore its history and architecture, and make the most of your visit to this famous bridge._
[](https://vivavn.com/japanese-covered-bridge/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/japanese-covered-bridge/#comment "Comment")
History and cultural significance
Bridge architecture
Visitor guide
FAQs
_Dear reader, every photo and video you see in this post was taken by us. This article may contain affiliate links—if you find something helpful and decide to make a purchase, it supports our work at no extra cost to you. Thank you for being here!_
## History and cultural significance
_The Japanese Covered Bridge spans a small waterway in Hoi An, surrounded by the town’s signature yellow-walled houses_
Back in the 16th century, Hoi An was one of the busiest international trading ports in [Southeast Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southeast_Asia). Ships from Japan, China, and even Europe anchored here, turning the town into a true cultural crossroads. Among the many foreign merchants, the Japanese and the Chinese were especially influential. They didn’t just trade goods; they also left behind lasting marks on the town’s architecture and cultural identity.
Temples, assembly halls such as [the Fujian Assembly Hall](https://vivavn.com/fujian-assembly-hall/), shophouses, and family homes began to appear, many of which still stand today. But perhaps the most iconic structure of all is the Japanese Covered Bridge. Thought to have been built in the late 16th or early 17th century, the bridge was funded by Japanese merchants and crafted by Vietnamese carpenters. Later, when the Japanese community declined, Chinese merchants took over its care and added a small temple at the back of the bridge.
The mix of Japanese, Chinese, and Vietnamese influences is what makes the bridge stand out. More than just a way to cross the water, it reflects Hoi An’s history as a place where different cultures came together.
_From the Japanese Covered Bridge looking out to the Hoai River_
## Architecture of the Japanese Covered Bridge
The Japanese Covered Bridge is about 18 meters long, a little over 10 meters wide including the small temple, and around 6 meters high. Its structure is mainly divided into two parts: the wooden bridge with its tiled roof, and a small temple attached to the bridge.
### **The wooden bridge and its tiled roof**
The bridge is mainly wooden, its floorboards, beams, and pillars carefully crafted and fitted together. Above, a tiled roof provides shade and shelter, turning the bridge into more than just a walkway. The entire structure is supported by stone pillars rising from the water below.
The roof is covered with traditional tiles similar to those found on Vietnamese temples and pagodas. Along the roofline are porcelain decorations featuring dragons, phoenixes, and cloud motifs.
_The facade of the Japanese Covered Bridge_
_Inside the Japanese Covered Bridge, with its wooden floorboards, beams, and pillars._
At both ends of the Japanese Covered Bridge, you’ll see statues of a pair of dogs and a pair of monkeys. The exact purpose of these statues isn’t entirely clear. Some say they mark the years the bridge was started and completed, since the dog and the monkey are zodiac animals in the Vietnamese lunar calendar. Others believe they carry spiritual significance in Japanese culture.
_Dog statue at one end of the Japanese Covered Bridge_
_Monkey statue at the Japanese Covered Bridge._
### **The temple on the bridge**
When the Japanese traders left Hoi An, the Chinese community took over the bridge and later added a small temple at its back.
Above the entrance of the temple, you’ll see a plaque with three Chinese characters. This is the official name of the bridge, given by Lord Nguyen Phuc Chu during his visit in 1719. The name means “the bridge welcomes travelers from afar.”
Just below the plaque are two round wooden blocks, known locally as “door eyes.” Common in old Hoi An houses, they’re believed to greet good guests while keeping away unwanted spirits.
Inside the temple, you’ll find an altar dedicated to the Northern God, a Taoist deity believed to bring peace and protection to the local community. During the full moon festivals and Vietnamese New Year, locals come here to offer incense, showing their respect and devotion while asking for blessings from the deity.
_The temple with three doorways, a name plaque, and round ‘door eyes’._
_Altar to the Northern God inside the temple_
## Everything you need to know before visiting the Japanese Covered Bridge
**Address:** At the end of Tran Phu Street, Hoi An Ancient Town.
**Opening hours:** 9:00 AM – 10:00 PM daily
**Tickets:** You’ll need a Hoi An Ancient Town entrance ticket (120,000 VND, about 5 USD per person). This ticket gives you access to five attractions of your choice, which can include assembly halls, old houses, museums, and temples. Tickets are sold at official booths scattered around the old town.
**Our tip:** Visit before 8:00 AM when the Japanese Covered Bridge is still quiet with very few visitors. This is the best time to enjoy the atmosphere and capture great photos without the crowds.
_Note: You can actually walk across the bridge at any time of day without showing a ticket. The ticket is only required if you’d like to step inside the small temple on the bridge._
## Frequently asked questions about visiting the Japanese Covered Bridge
### Do I need a ticket to visit the Japanese Covered Bridge?
Yes, you’ll need a Hoi An Ancient Town entrance ticket (120,000 VND, about 5 USD), which includes access to the bridge and four other attractions of your choice.
### What are the opening hours of the Japanese Covered Bridge?
It’s officially open from 9:00 AM to 10:00 PM daily, but you can walk by and see it from outside at any time.
### How old is the Japanese Covered Bridge?
The bridge was built more than 400 years ago, around the late 16th or early 17th century, during Hoi An’s golden age as a trading port.
### Why is it called the Japanese Covered Bridge?
Because it was originally built by the Japanese trading community in Hoi An. Later, the Chinese community added a small temple to it.
### Can you take photos inside the Japanese Covered Bridge?
Yes, photography is allowed both inside and outside the bridge. Early morning gives the best light and fewer people.

# Vietnamese Soursop Tea Bags: Flavors and Health Benefits
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/tea/)
Tea
[](https://vivavn.com/category/soursop/)
Soursop
[](https://youtube.com/shorts/vF43RKyf4sE?si=Az3W0Rgau6hoKbyO)
_This article will delve into Vietnamese soursop tea bags, examining their distinctive flavors, potential health benefits, and how to brew the perfect cup._
Share on FacebookShare on X (Twitter)Share on PinterestShare on LinkedinShare on Email
## Key takeaways from this article
How to make Vietnamese soursop tea bags
The taste of Vietnamese soursop tea bags
Health benefits of soursop 
## Ingredients
Vietnamese soursop tea bags
Honey or any sweetener
Ice cubes
Lemon
Hot water
A glass and a spoon 
## Brewing instructions
1. You’ll need soursop tea bags, fresh water, and any sweeteners or additives you prefer, such as honey or lemon.
2. Heat fresh, filtered water in a kettle or pot until it reaches a rolling boil.
3. Place a soursop tea bag in your cup or mug.
4. Once the water has boiled, carefully pour it over the soursop tea bag in your cup. Fill the cup to your desired level, but leave some space at the top to prevent spillage.
5. Allow the soursop tea bag to steep in the hot water for about 4 to 5 minutes. This allows the flavors to infuse fully into the water, resulting in a tasty and aromatic cup of tea.
6. After the steeping time is up, carefully remove the soursop tea bag from the cup. You can gently squeeze the bag against the side of the cup with a spoon to extract any remaining liquid.
7. If desired, add any sweeteners or flavorings to the cup.
8. Your soursop tea is now ready to drink! Take a moment to appreciate the aroma before taking a sip. Soursop tea can be enjoyed hot or chilled, depending on your preference.
9. If desired, you can add additional flavorings such as a slice of lemon or a sprig of mint to enhance the taste of your tea.
## The taste of Vietnamese soursop tea bags
Vietnamese soursop tea bags offer a unique and refreshing flavor profile that combines the tartness of soursop with a subtly sweet and floral undertone. The aroma of soursop tea is equally enticing, with hints of tropical fruits and floral notes
## Health benefits of soursop
In traditional Vietnamese medicine, different parts of the soursop plant, like the leaves, fruit, roots, and seeds, are believed to have healing properties. Vietnamese people drink soursop tea to reduce stress, improve skin health, and stabilize blood pressure.
### According to Healthline.com, a 3.5-ounce (100-gram) serving of raw soursop contains:
Calories: 66
Protein: 1 gram
Carbs: 16.8 grams
Fiber: 3.3 grams
Vitamin C: 34% of the recommended daily intake (RDI)
Potassium: 8% of the RDI
Magnesium: 5% of the RDI
Thiamine: 5% of the RDI
### Healthline.com also lists the health benefits of soursop:
1. It’s high in Antioxidants: Antioxidants may help reduce the risk of various diseases like heart disease, cancer, and diabetes.
2. It may help kill cancer cells: Studies suggest soursop could have anti-cancer properties.

[](https://vivavn.com)
# The Red-Shanked Douc Langur in Son Tra Peninsula
3 min
[](https://vivavn.com/da-nang/)
Da Nang
[](https://youtu.be/vPUVTIa9vqE)
_[Son Tra Peninsula](https://vivavn.com/son-tra-peninsula/) is home to rare and precious red-shanked douc langurs, often regarded as the queens of primates due to their stunning five-colored fur coats. Visiting Son Tra Peninsula to observe these adorable creatures is an unforgettable experience._
Share on FacebookShare on X (Twitter)Share on PinterestShare on LinkedinShare on Email
## Key takeaways from this article
Things to know before you go
Tips for observing red-shanked douc langurs
Learn about red-shanked douc langurs and their habitat  

## Things to know before you go
**Location:** The red-shanked douc langurs live on Son Tra Peninsula, in the city of Da Nang.
**English Name:** Red-shanked douc langur
**Latin Name (Scientific):** Pygathrix nemaeus
**Population:** 300-350 red-shanked douc langurs on Son Tra Peninsula.
**Endangered status:** Classified as endangered (EN) on the IUCN Red List and in the Vietnam Red Data Book (2007).
**Color:** Red-shanked douc langurs have a vibrant multi-colored fur coat consisting of gold, brown or reddish-brown, orange, gray, black, and white.
**Family unit structure:** Red-shanked douc langurs live in separate family units, each consisting of one adult male, 2-3 females, and their offspring
## Tips for observing red-shanked douc langurs on Son Tra Peninsula.
**Visit early morning or late afternoon:** Red-shanked douc langurs are often more active during these times, increasing your chances of spotting them.
**Look up!:** Langurs spend most of their time in the trees, so be sure to look up in the canopy as you walk through the forest.
**Bring binoculars:** A good pair of binoculars will help you get a better view of the langurs once you spot them.
**Stay quiet and patient:** Loud noises can scare the langurs away. Be patient and quiet to increase your chances of observing them in their natural habitat.
## Learn about red-shanked douc langurs and their habitat
We’ll provide you with some information about red-shanked douc langurs on Son Tra Peninsula.
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
### Gender size
Adult males are much larger than females. An adult male’s length ranges from 55-63cm, averaging 59.6cm, while females are around 50-57cm. In weight, males range from 5.8 – 11kg, while females weigh about 6.4 – 8kg.
### Color
Both adult males and females have similar colors. Red-shanked douc langurs, often referred to as the Queen of Primates, boast a vibrant fur coat with colors including gold, brown or reddish-brown, orange, gray, black, and white.
### Reproduction and lifespan
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Female red-shanked douc langurs can start giving birth at about 3 years old, while males usually begin mating at age 4 or 5. The reproductive lifespan of a female lasts about 5-8 years.
### Food
Red-shanked douc langurs primarily eat leaves, but they also consume fruits or seeds occasionally, depending on the season. In Son Tra, they have a diverse diet, feeding on over 150 different plant species, including trees, vines, and medicinal plants.
### Daily activities and social organization
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Red-shanked douc langurs are daytime creatures and mostly live in trees. They prefer tall, thickly branched trees for sleeping and never sleep in caves or on rock ledges. These chosen sleeping trees are usually sheltered from the wind, and they return to them to sleep repeatedly.
In terms of social life, red-shanked douc langurs live in separate family units, each consisting of only one adult male, 2-3 females, and their offspring. Occasionally during the day, multiple families may come together to form a large herd of over 50 individuals.
Their daily activities typically include resting, eating, moving, and socializing.
### Facing extinction threats
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
[The IUCN Red List](https://www.iucnredlist.org/species/39826/17941247) categorizes the red-shanked douc langur as critically endangered due to increasing concerns about threats to its survival beyond natural factors..
In Vietnam, the red-shanked douc langur is also strictly protected by laws, decrees, and regulations of the Vietnamese government. The Vietnam Red Data Book also classifies this species as endangered (EN).
The photos in the article were taken by Huy Dope, a talented photographer who currently works at a paragliding club on Son Tra Peninsula.

# Piper Lolot vs Betel Leaf: What’s the Difference?
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/herbs/)
Herbs
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial)
_Ever wondered whether the leaf in your Vietnamese grilled beef is the same as the one used in traditional betel chewing? Piper lolot (commonly known as “wild betel leaf”) and Betel leaf (Piper betle) may look similar, but they serve very different purposes. In this article, we’ll compare Piper lolot vs Betel leaf in terms of appearance, taste, and culinary use._
[](https://vivavn.com/piper-lolot-vs-betel-leaf/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/piper-lolot-vs-betel-leaf/#comment "Comment")

## What is piper lolot?
Piper lolot (_Piper sarmentosum_), also known as wild betel leaf or “la lot” in Vietnamese, is a tropical herb native to Southeast Asia. It has a distinctive aroma that is highly prized in Vietnamese cuisine, commonly featured in dishes such as grilled beef wrapped in piper lolot (_bo nuong la lot_), stir-fried beef with piper lolot (_bo xao la lot_), as well as in various stir-fries and soups.
Our detailed article: [Piper Lolot in Vietnam: Guide and Culinary Uses](https://vivavn.com/piper-lolot/)
_Close-up of a piper lolot leaf in a Vietnamese garden_
## What is betel leaf?
Betel leaf (_Piper betle_) is a leaf traditionally used in Vietnamese and Southeast Asian cultures. Unlike piper lolot, it’s rarely used in cooking. Instead, betel leaf plays a key role in rituals and ceremonies, often chewed with areca nut and symbolizing respect and longevity.
_Close-up of a betel leaf growing fresh in a Vietnamese garden_
## **Key differences between piper lolot and betel leaf**
### Appearance and growth habits
#### **Leaves**
Both piper lolot and betel leaf have a heart-shaped appearance, but there are subtle differences. The betel leaf tends to be longer and narrower, almost tapering toward the tip, while the lolot leaf is slightly shorter, wider, and more rounded, giving it a fuller, softer look overall. Both leaves are deep green in color, but the surface of the betel leaf is glossier and smoother.
_Side-by-side comparison of piper lolot and betel leaf—showing differences in shape and surface texture._
_The back side of piper lolot and betel leaf_
#### **Stem comparison**
Both piper lolot and betel leaf have soft, segmented stems with visible nodes. However, piper lolot stems are typically lighter green when young, turning darker green as they mature. In contrast, betel leaf stems start out green but gradually shift to a purplish hue with age.
_This close-up image shows the stems of piper lolot plants_
_The image highlights the stems of the betel leaf plant_
#### **Growing environment:**
Piper lolot prefers shady, damp environments. It grows close to the ground and thrives under the canopy of larger plants or trees, away from direct sunlight. Betel leaf, on the other hand, is a climbing vine. It grows best with vertical support—like a wall or trellis—and does well in warm, humid spots with filtered light.
_Healthy piper lolot plants growing in the natural shade beneath a large tree in a Vietnamese garden._
_Betel leaf grows as a climbing vine and often needs vertical support_
### **Taste and aroma**
When fresh, piper lolot has a mild spiciness with a slight tingling sensation on the tongue and a hint of bitterness. Its flavor is pleasantly aromatic and never overpowering. Once added to hot dishes, its aroma deepens, becoming rich, fragrant, and savory.
Betel leaf has a bold, peppery flavor with a sharp, almost medicinal aroma. It delivers a warm, slightly spicy bite with a hint of bitterness and a pungent, herbal aftertaste that some find overpowering.
## How Piper lolot and betel leaf are used in Vietnamese cuisine and culture
In Vietnam, Piper lolot (_la lot_) and betel leaf (_la trau_) are used in very different ways—one in the kitchen, the other in tradition.
Piper lolot is a beloved [cooking herb in Vietnamese cuisine](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-herbs/). Its mildly spicy, aromatic flavor makes it perfect for wrapping meats in dishes like grilled beef in lolot leaf or stir-fried beef with piper lolot. It’s also used in stir-fries and soups.
Betel leaf, on the other hand, plays a more cultural and ceremonial role. It’s rarely eaten as food, but traditionally chewed with areca nut as part of social rituals, especially among older generations. Betel leaves are also featured in wedding ceremonies and ancestral offerings, symbolizing respect, connection, and love.
Though they may look similar, their roles in Vietnamese life couldn’t be more different—one flavors the meal, the other carries meaning.
_A flavorful Vietnamese stir-fry featuring tender beef and aromatic piper lolot leaves_
_A Vietnamese set of betel leaves, areca nut, and lime paste_
## FAQs about piper lolot and betel leaf
### Is a betel leaf the same as a lolot leaf?
No, they are not the same. While piper lolot (wild betel leaf) and betel leaf (piper betle) may look similar, they are different plants with different uses. Piper lolot is used in cooking, especially in Vietnamese dishes like grilled beef in lolot leaves. Betel leaf, on the other hand, is used in traditional ceremonies and is typically chewed with areca nut.
### What does piper lolot taste like?
Piper lolot has a mild, peppery flavor with a slight bitterness and a gently aromatic aftertaste. When cooked, its fragrance deepens, giving dishes a rich, savory aroma. It’s never overpowering and pairs especially well with grilled or stir-fried meats.
### Can you substitute something else for piper lolot?
While piper lolot has a unique flavor, you can try using [perilla leaves (shiso) ](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-perilla/)as a substitute in wrapping dishes. However, they won’t replicate the exact aroma and taste.

# Vietnamese Watermelon: A Guide to Varieties, Health Benefits, and Recipes
We will bring you all the essential and useful information about Vietnamese watermelons.
7 min
[](https://vivavn.com/fruit/)
Fruit
[](https://youtu.be/sYXG1vemrX8)
_As the summer sun beats down, there’s nothing quite as refreshing as biting into a juicy, ripe watermelon. And when it comes to watermelons, Vietnam has some of the world’s sweetest and most flavorful varieties. These delicious fruits have been cultivated in the fertile lands of Vietnam for centuries, and their unique taste and texture are a true delight._
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial "YouTube")
[](https://www.facebook.com/vivavnofficial2024 "Facebook")
[](https://www.pinterest.com/vivavnofficial/ "Pinterest")
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
### [Vietnamese Coconut Nectar: Sokfarm’s Sustainable Sweetener](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
In this article, I’ll take you on a journey through the world of Vietnamese watermelons, exploring their different varieties, the legend of the Vietnamese watermelon, health benefits, delicious recipes, and how Vietnamese farmers grow these wonderful fruits.
## The legend of the Vietnamese watermelon
Once upon a time, there was a man named Mai An Tiêm who was beloved by King Hung and adopted as his son. One day, due to a misunderstanding of An Tiêm’s words, the king became angry and exiled him to a deserted island.
On the island, An Tiêm and his wife built a house from bamboo and made clothes from dried grass. One day, An Tiêm saw a flock of birds dropping black seeds. He picked up the seeds, planted them in the sand, and thought, “If birds can eat this, so can people.” Soon, the seeds grew into a sprawling vine, which produced fruit with dark green skin, red flesh, black seeds, and a sweet, refreshing taste. An Tiêm and his wife planted these fruits all over the island.
When the fruit was ripe, An Tiêm carved his name into one of them and let it float out to sea, hoping the waves would carry it to the mainland. A local fisherman found the unusual fruit and brought it to the king. Realizing his mistake, the king welcomed An Tiêm and his wife back home.
The strange fruit was what we now call watermelon, or “dưa hấu” in Vietnamese.
## Growing and harvesting Watermelons in Vietnam
In northern Vietnam, the cold winter weather makes it difficult for watermelons to grow. Therefore, there are two growing seasons each year in this region: one in spring, where seeds are planted at the end of February and harvested in May, and another in summer, where seeds are planted in June and harvested in August.
In central and southern Vietnam, the climate is ideal for growing watermelons, so they are cultivated throughout the year.
Typically, in Vietnam, harvesting begins 30 to 35 days after pollination. To ensure the watermelons are sweet and of good quality, farmers reduce or stop watering the plants 7 to 10 days before harvest, depending on the soil conditions. After that, they carefully cut and transport the watermelons, using straw to cushion them and prevent bruising.
## Vietnam’s top watermelon-growing regions
In Vietnam, watermelons are cultivated across the entire country, thriving in several key regions. In the North, you’ll find major production areas in Hanoi, Hai Duong, Nam Dinh, Thai Binh, Vinh Phuc, and Phu Tho. Moving to the Central Coast, Quang Nam, Quang Ngai, Binh Dinh, and Phu Yen are the hotspots for watermelon farming. Down in the Mekong Delta, the provinces of Long An, Dong Thap, Soc Trang, Hau Giang, Can Tho, Vinh Long, Tra Vinh, and Tien Giang are particularly prominent for their watermelon production.
## Watermelon growing conditions
### Weather
Watermelons thrive in warm weather and require dry conditions with plenty of sunshine to produce quality fruit.
### Soil
They grow best in well-drained soils such as sandy, sandy loam, or alluvial soils.
### **pH and temperature**
The optimal pH range for soil is between 6.0 and 7.0, and the ideal temperature range is 25-30°C.
### Day and night conditions
Cool nights and warm days are ideal as they help with the accumulation of sugars in the fruit, enhancing sweetness.
## The different varieties of Vietnamese watermelon
### Red-fleshed watermelon
Red-fleshed watermelons are the most popular variety in Vietnam for several reasons. First, the vibrant red color is highly favored in Vietnamese culture, symbolizing luck, prosperity, and happiness.
Additionally, this type of watermelon is well-suited to Vietnam’s natural conditions, making it easy to cultivate. The combination of cultural significance and suitability for local growing conditions has made red-fleshed watermelons a favorite among both farmers and consumers.
### Yellow-fleshed watermelon
The reason some watermelons have yellow flesh is due to the pigments they contain. While red-fleshed watermelons are rich in lycopene, which gives them their red color, yellow-fleshed watermelons have less lycopene and more beta-carotene. Beta-carotene is the pigment responsible for the yellow or orange color in these watermelons.
### Seedless watermelon
Seedless watermelons aren’t completely seedless. They have fewer seeds than regular watermelons, and the seeds are less developed. You might still find some small, immature seeds in them. This happens because seedless watermelons are bred to have the fruit ripen faster than the seeds can mature. Once the watermelon is picked, the seeds stop developing.
## Nutritional facts of watermelon
Watermelon is delicious and full of essential nutrients with many health benefits. Here’s a look at its nutritional profile:
**Water content:** Watermelon is aptly named, as it’s composed of around 91% water, making it an excellent choice for staying hydrated, especially during the hot summer months.
**Vitamins and minerals:** This juicy fruit is a good source of vitamins A, C, and B5, as well as potassium, and copper.
**High citrulline and lycopene:** Watermelon is rich in citrulline and lycopene. **[Citrulline](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6369322/)** helps lower blood pressure, while **[lycopene](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35216071/),** which gives watermelon its red color, is a powerful antioxidant that supports heart health and boosts vitamin A production.
**Low in Calories and Fat** : Despite its sweet flavor, watermelon is relatively low in calories and contains no fat.
For a detailed breakdown of its nutritional components, including vitamins, minerals, and other key nutrients, you can check the comprehensive data available **[here](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/167765/nutrients)**.
## Health benefits of watermelon
**Supports heart health** : Watermelon is rich in citrulline, an amino acid that can help improve blood flow and lower blood pressure, reducing the risk of heart disease.
**Boosts immune function** : With its high vitamin C content, watermelon can help strengthen the immune system and protect against infections.
**Aids hydration** : As mentioned earlier, watermelon’s high water content makes it an excellent choice for staying hydrated, especially during hot weather or physical activity.
**Supports muscle recovery** : Watermelon is a good source of citrulline, an amino acid that can help reduce muscle soreness and improve recovery after [**exercise**](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6099278/).
## Exploring Vietnamese watermelon recipes
We’re excited to bring you some easy and refreshing watermelon recipes that anyone can make.
### Watermelon smoothie
**Ingredients:**
100g watermelon
2 teaspoons honey
1 teaspoon sugar
Ice cubes
**Instructions:**
**Step 1:** Start by peeling the watermelon, remove the seeds, and cut the flesh into small pieces.
**Step 2:** Place 100g of the chopped watermelon into a blender. Add 2 teaspoons of honey, 1 teaspoon of sugar, and a few ice cubes.
**Step 3:** Blend everything for 3-5 minutes until smooth. If the smoothie is too thick, add more ice or a splash of water and blend again.
**Step 4:** Pour the watermelon smoothie into a glass and enjoy!
### Watermelon carrot juice
**Ingredients:**
1/4 watermelon
1 carrot
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 cup of ice
**Instructions:**
St**ep 1:** Peel 1/4 of a watermelon, remove the seeds, and cut the flesh into pieces.
**Step 2:** Peel the carrot and cut it into small pieces.
Step 3**:** Juice the watermelon and carrot together, then add 1/4 teaspoon of salt.
**Step 4:** Pour the juice over ice and enjoy!
### Roasted watermelon seeds (hạt dưa)
Roasted watermelon seeds (hạt dưa) are an essential snack during the Vietnamese Lunar New Year (**[Tết](https://vivavn.com/what-is-tet/)**). They are often served to guests or enjoyed by family members throughout the holiday, symbolizing luck and prosperity for the new year.
## Carved watermelons for the Lunar New Year
In Vietnam, during the Lunar New Year, it’s a tradition to buy watermelons with intricate carvings of letters or symbols to place on the ancestral altar. For Vietnamese people, these specially carved watermelons symbolize prosperity and luck for the coming year.
## How to pick a ripe Vietnamese watermelon
### Check the stem
Look for a dried, curly stem. A green or moist stem indicates the watermelon may not be fully ripe.
### Examine the filed spot
The field spot is the large, creamy yellow area where the watermelon rested on the ground. A deep yellow spot suggests ripeness and sweetness, while a white spot might mean it’s not as ripe.
### Inspect the color
Choose a watermelon with a dark green color and a strong, consistent stripe pattern. This indicates a ripe fruit.
### Tap the watermelon
When you tap a ripe watermelon with your hand or fist, it should make a deep sound.
### Choose the heaviest one
If the melons are similar in size, pick the heaviest one. It’s likely to be juicier.

# Vietnamese Rambutan: Everything You Need to Know About This Tropical Treat
We’re excited to share some valuable insights about Vietnamese rambutan with you.
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/fruit/)
Fruit
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oybkJyucFVc)
_Rambutan is a fruit that’s as fun to look at as it is to eat. With its spiky red shell and sweet, juicy flesh, it’s a true tropical delight. In this article, we’ll introduce you to this interesting fruit, explain its delicious flavor, and show you why it’s becoming a favorite among fruit lovers. Come along as we explore the world of Vietnamese rambutan and how you can enjoy this exotic treat! Plus, stick around for some[fun quizzes](https://vivavn.com/rambutan/#vietnamese-rambutan-quiz) at the end to test your knowledge about this fascinating fruit!_
[](https://www.youtube.com/@VivaVNOfficial "YouTube")
[](https://www.facebook.com/vivavnofficial2024 "Facebook")
[](https://www.pinterest.com/vivavnofficial/ "Pinterest")
[](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
### [Vietnamese Coconut Nectar: Sokfarm’s Sustainable Sweetener](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-coconut-nectar/)
## What is rambutan fruit?
Rambutan is a small, round, or oval fruit, typically measuring 3-6 cm long and 3-4 cm wide. It grows in clusters of 10-20 fruits, with a vibrant red or yellow skin covered with soft, hair-like spikes that give it a unique and exotic appearance. Inside, the fruit reveals a whitish, translucent flesh that is juicy and attaches to a large seed at its center.
Rambutan trees typically grow between 12 and 20 meters tall. However, through selective cloning, shorter varieties have been developed that only reach 3 to 5 meters. These compact trees are much easier to harvest.
In Vietnam, rambutan trees are usually propagated through grafting, as growing them from seeds often results in lower yields. Farmers prefer grafting to ensure higher productivity. Rambutan trees typically begin bearing fruit after 4 to 5 years, with peak production occurring between 8 to 10 years. The fruit takes about 100 to 120 days to ripen from the time the flowers bloom.
Rambutan trees thrive in temperatures between 22-30°C but struggle in extreme conditions—flowers and fruit drop significantly when temperatures exceed 40°C, while cooler temperatures below 22°C slow down flowering. In Vietnam, the rambutan harvest season generally runs from May to July each year.
Young rambutan fruits
A rambutan tree can grow over 10 meters tall.
A rambutan tree stands at about 3 meters tall, making it easy to harvest.
## Flavor profile
Rambutan has a sweet, tropical aroma with a subtle hint of mango and vanilla. Its flavor is smooth and gentle, making it very pleasant and easy to enjoy. The white flesh of ripe rambutan has a sweet and subtly tangy flavor. Its texture is soft and juicy, with a slight chewiness.
## Nutritional highlights of rambutan
The United States Department of Agriculture (**[USDA](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/168167/nutrients)**) Nutrient Database doesn’t provide nutrition facts for fresh rambutan. However, they do list the nutritional information for rambutan canned in syrup, drained, with a serving size of 1 cup (150g).
**Nutrient** | **Amount**  
---|---  
**Water** | 117 g  
**Energy** | 123 kcal  
**Carbohydrates** | 31.4 g  
**Fiber** | 1.35 g  
**Protein** | 0.975 g  
**Fat** | 0.315 g  
**Vitamin C** | 7.35 mg  
**Iron** | 0.525 mg  
**Calcium** | 33 mg  
**Potassium** | 63 mg  
**Magnesium** | 10.5 mg  
## How to eat rambutan: a step-by-step guide
**Select the Fruit** :
Choose ripe rambutan, which has a vibrant red or yellow skin. Avoid green or overly dark fruits, as they may be sour or overripe.
**Prepare the fruit** :
Hold the rambutan firmly. Use your fingers or a knife to carefully peel away the spiky, hairy outer skin.
**Extract the flesh and enjoy:**
To separate the juicy flesh from the seed, gently use a knife to slice around the seed or carefully remove the flesh away with your fingers. Alternatively, you can place the rambutan in your mouth and carefully bite into the flesh, making sure not to bite the seed as it is bitter and unpleasant.
## How to store rambutan
When storing rambutan at room temperature, you might notice that the fruit loses weight quickly due to moisture loss. Over a period of 5 to 8 days, rambutan can lose between 22% and 25% of its weight, depending on the variety. The higher the temperature, the more weight the fruit will lose.
To keep rambutan fresh for a longer period, store it in a plastic bag in the refrigerator at 10°C (50°F). This method can extend the fruit’s freshness for up to 2 weeks.
## Fresh rambutan or preserved alternatives
The best way to truly savor the flavor of rambutan is to eat it fresh. There’s nothing quite like the juicy, sweet taste of a ripe rambutan right off the tree. However, since rambutan is a seasonal fruit, it might not always be available. When fresh rambutan isn’t in season, you can still enjoy this tropical delight by opting for canned rambutan or dried rambutan. These alternatives capture the essence of the fruit, letting you experience its unique flavor even when it’s not in season.
### What is canned rambutan?
Canned rambutan is rambutan that has been processed and preserved in tin cans, usually in a sugary syrup to keep the fruit fresh for longer. This is a convenient way to enjoy rambutan when it’s out of season or when fresh rambutan isn’t available.
Fruit producers in Vietnam have developed this canned rambutan product, bringing the unique flavor of this tropical fruit to consumers around the world. The canning process helps retain the fruit’s flavor and quality, though it might not be quite the same as eating it fresh. Canned rambutan can be used as a dessert or an ingredient in various dishes, adding convenience and variety to your menu.
### What is dried rambutan?
Dried rambutan is a convenient way to enjoy this tropical fruit even when it’s out of season. The drying process removes moisture, concentrating the fruit’s natural sweetness and giving it a chewy texture.
While it may not have the same juiciness as fresh rambutan, dried rambutan retains many of its nutrients, including fiber. It’s perfect for snacking, baking, or adding a tropical twist to various dishes. Produced by Vietnamese manufacturers, dried rambutan is typically packaged in sealed bags to maintain its flavor and quality.

# Areca Leaf Plates: What They Are, How They’re Made, and How to Use Them
3 min
[](https://vivavn.com/eco-friendly-products/)
Eco products
Areca leaf
[](https://youtu.be/cpAEcJz84CI)
_If you’ve ever thrown a picnic or party, you know how fast disposable plates add up—and most aren’t great for the planet. That’s where areca leaf plates come in. Made from naturally fallen palm leaves, they’re eco-friendly, sturdy, chemical-free, and beautifully unique. In this post, we’ll look at what they are, how they’re made in Vietnam, and why they’re winning over eco-conscious eaters and event planners worldwide._
[](https://vivavn.com/areca-leaf-plates/#title-hoi-an-villages "Back to top")
[](https://vivavn.com/areca-leaf-plates/#comment "Comment")
What are areca leaf plates?
How they’re made
How to use
Key benefits
FAQs
## What are areca leaf plates?
Areca leaf plates are made from the naturally shed [leaf sheaths](https://vivavn.com/areca-leaf-sheaths/) of the [areca palm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Areca). These sheaths are the thick bases of the leaves that wrap around the trunk of the tree. As they naturally fall off and dry, they become a firm material ideal for crafting. The plates are made entirely from these sheaths without chemicals or adhesives, making them safe and eco-friendly. No trees are cut down in the process.
_A row of tall areca palm trees in Vietnam_
_An areca palm leaf turning yellow, a sign of aging before it naturally falls to the ground_
_A fallen areca palm leaf lies on the ground. Its sheath — the thick base that once wrapped around the trunk — is the part used to make eco-friendly plates and bowls._
## How are areca leaf plates made in Vietnam?
The production of areca leaf plates begins with selecting only leaves that meet quality standards—strong, durable, and with attractive natural patterns—while discarding any that don’t.
These chosen leaves are then shaped into plates using a heat press machine. Once formed, the plates are sterilized to ensure they meet high hygiene standards, making them safe and ready for use.
_A local worker in Vietnam shapes an areca leaf into a plate using a heat press machine_
_A collection of biodegradable plates, bowls, and spoons crafted from areca palm leaves, each with unique natural patterns so no two are exactly alike._
## How to use areca leaf plates
Areca leaf plates are ready to use straight out of the package. They are perfect for serving meals at parties, picnics, weddings, or everyday dining. Each plate showcases beautiful natural colors and unique patterns, so no two are exactly alike.
They are strong enough for both hot and cold foods, and fully biodegradable, making cleanup simple and eco-friendly. After use, simply throw them away with other organic or biodegradable waste.
## Benefits of areca leaf plates
Areca leaf plates offer several advantages that make them a smart choice for both everyday dining and special events:
**Eco-friendly and biodegradable** – Made from naturally fallen areca palm leaves, they break down naturally without harming the environment.
**Chemical-free and safe** – No chemicals, glue, or coatings are used, so they are completely food-safe.
**Strong and durable** – Areca leaf plates can hold hot or cold foods.
**Unique and beautiful look** – Each plate has its own natural patterns and colors, adding a rustic, stylish touch to your table.
## Frequently asked questions
### Which part of the areca palm leaf is used to make plates?
Only the leaf sheath — the thick base of the leaf that naturally wraps around the tree trunk. When it falls to the ground and dries, it becomes strong enough to be shaped into plates and bowls.
### Are areca leaf plates safe for food?
Yes. They are chemical-free, toxin-free, and completely safe for both hot and cold foods.
### Are areca leaf plates better than paper or plastic plates?
Absolutely. Unlike plastic, they biodegrade naturally, and unlike paper, they don’t require cutting down trees. Plus, each plate has unique natural patterns that look stylish on any table.

# Thanh Ha Pottery Village: Your Ultimate Guide to a 500-Year-Old Craft Village+ Videos
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/countryside/)
Countryside
[](https://youtu.be/eNut1ASJV98)
_In this article, we’re excited to show you Thanh Ha Pottery Village near Hoi An. Learn about the history of this traditional craft, and see the beautiful pottery. We’ll give you tips on how to get there, what to expect, and fun pottery workshops you can join. Whether you love art or just want a special experience, this guide will help you enjoy your visit to this lovely village!_
What makes Thanh Ha Village special?
Experiences in Thanh Ha
Directions & transport
Entrance fee
## What makes Thanh Ha Pottery Village special?
One of the [must-visit villages in Hoi An](https://vivavn.com/hoi-an-villages/) is Thanh Ha Pottery Village, and it has a charm that sets it apart from other villages in the area. Let’s dive in and explore what makes this village special!
### A legacy of pottery-making that spans 500 years
Thanh Ha Pottery Village was founded in the 16th century, and according to historical records, the first settlers were people from Thanh Hoa, which is about 650 kilometers north of Hoi An. They brought their pottery-making skills with them to build the village. Initially, they focused on crafting everyday pottery items like pots, bowls, plates, and teapots to serve the central region of Vietnam.
The village thrived the most during the 17th and 18th centuries, when [Hoi An](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An) was a bustling trading port, attracting merchants from Japan, China, and the West. During this time, in addition to everyday products, Thanh Ha also began producing containers for export goods.
### Unique traditional pottery-making techniques
One of the most distinctive aspects of Thanh Ha Pottery is its traditional and nearly unique production methods that have been preserved for centuries. The primary material used is brown clay sourced from the Thu Bon River. The artisans here maintain a completely manual production process, shaping the pottery by hand or using a foot-powered wheel, without the use of molds.
What truly sets Thanh Ha apart is the intuitive way the artisans fire their pottery. They don’t rely on temperature measuring tools; instead, they gauge the heat and timing based on their experience and the sound of the fire. Another fascinating aspect is that the absence of glaze and chemical additives results in a diverse range of colors in the finished pieces, such as golden red, brick red, brown, pink, and black.
## What exciting experiences await you in Thanh Ha Pottery Village?
### Watch the artisans craft pottery
When you visit this village, you’ll see how the local artisans craft beautiful pottery from clay. These skilled craftsmen often start their work early in the morning and continue until late in the evening, working alone right in front of their homes, surrounded by rows of their handmade creations.
### Learn to make pottery
Not only can you watch the artisans in action, but you can also get hands-on and make your own pottery with their help. You’ll learn how to shape your creations by hand and add color to your pieces, and you can take home your masterpiece when the workshop is over. It’s a fun experience, and there’s a small fee to participate.
### Visit Thanh Ha Terracotta Park
In the village, you’ll find a spot known as Thanh Ha Terracotta Park, which showcases the products of the local artisans. The park also features pottery from other famous villages in Vietnam, like Bat Trang. One of the highlights of this place is its impressive displays of iconic architectural works from Vietnam and even some of the world’s wonders. It’s a great place to explore and appreciate the art of pottery
### Taking a boat ride on the Thu Bồn River
After exploring Thanh Ha Pottery Village, you can head to the Thu Bon River and take a boat ride back to Hoi An Ancient Town. This delightful experience allows you to take in the scenic countryside on both sides of the river and get a glimpse of the local life along the way.
## How to get to Thanh Ha Pottery Village from Hoi An Ancient Town
Thanh Ha Pottery Village is located about 4 kilometers west of Hoi An’s Ancient Town, and getting there is a breeze. You can reach the village by taxi, Grab, motorbike, bicycle, or even on foot. Just like other villages in the area, we recommend biking for the best experience. Renting a bike is easy, and you’ll find plenty of rental shops around the Old Town.
## Is there an entrance fee for Thanh Ha Pottery Village
The entrance fee for Thanh Ha Pottery Village is about 35,000 VND (about $1.50) for adults and 15,000 VND (about $0.65) for children. With this ticket, you can explore the village and watch the artisans at work. If you want to visit the Thanh Ha Terracotta Park, you’ll need a separate ticket—50,000 VND (around $2.15) for adults and 30,000 VND (about $1.30) for kids. For pottery-making classes, you can contact the local workshops directly for pricing details.

# Vietnamese Green Tea Suppliers: Find the Finest Ones
We’ll provide useful information about the best green tea suppliers in Vietnam.
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/category/tea/)
Tea
_Did you know Vietnam boasts a tea tradition stretching back thousands of years? That’s right, even before tea became a global phenomenon, Vietnamese people enjoyed this delicious beverage.[ Vietnamese tea ](https://vivavn.com/vietnamese-tea/)has a unique flavor profile, making it a special experience. And the good news is, Vietnam has a thriving tea industry with many suppliers producing top-notch teas._
## Vietnamese green tea suppliers
### The Fin Ho tea cooperative
A centuries-old Shan Tuyet tea tree on the summit of Phin Ho Mountain (Image: FÌN HÒ TRÀ on Facebook)
Phin Ho Mountain peaks in Thong Nguyen commune, Hoang Su Phi district, Ha Giang province. This cool spot sits 1,300 meters above sea level. Year-round, clouds wrap the landscape, creating a refreshing and pure atmosphere. Here, nature generously gifts a treasure: the Shan Tuyet tea tree. These tea trees grow wild in the forests, reaching heights of 5 to 10 meters, with trunks over 20 centimeters in diameter and lifespans stretching hundreds of years.
FÌN HÒ TRÀ on Facebook
The Fin Ho Tea Cooperative is a collective business venture of 50 local households. They produce organic Shan Tuyet tea using the traditional methods of the Red Dao ethnic group. Through their special techniques, they craft Shan Tuyet tea with exceptional flavor. They offer five different teas: green, red, black, white, and Fairy tea. Each type boasts its unique aroma and taste, with prices ranging from a few tens of US dollars to several hundred US dollars per kilogram. In 2015, Fin Ho tea earned certification as an Organic EU product from the European Union alliance and is recognized as a 5-star [OCOP product of Vietnam](https://vivavn.com/what-is-ocop-vietnam/).
FÌN HÒ TRÀ on Facebook
### The Hao Dat Tea Cooperative
Image: Chè Hảo Đạt Tân Cương – Chè Sạch Thái Nguyên on Facebook
The Hao Dat Tea Cooperative, located in Tan Cuong commune, Thai Nguyen province, is a renowned producer of Tan Cuong green tea, a famous Vietnamese variety prized for its exceptional flavor thanks to the region’s ideal climate and terrain. They are a leader in applying scientific and technical advancements, ensuring consistent quality control throughout their process. Production capacity ranges from 4.0 to 4.5 tons of fresh tea buds per day. On average, the cooperative processes between 1,350 to 1,500 tons of fresh tea buds annually, supplying the market with 250 to 300 tons of dried tea buds each year.
Image: Chè Hảo Đạt Tân Cương – Chè Sạch Thái Nguyên on Facebook
Through a strong emphasis on applying scientific and technical advancements, the Hao Dat Tea Cooperative has established its brand and quality in both domestic and international markets. This producer boasts two products recognized as 5-star OCOP national products.
Image: Chè Hảo Đạt Tân Cương – Chè Sạch Thái Nguyên on Facebook
### Hoai Trung Premium “Dinh” Tea
Image: hoaitrungtea.com
Steeped in history, [Phu Tho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ph%C3%BA_Th%E1%BB%8D_province), considered the ancestral land of the Vietnamese people, boasts a tea cultivation tradition dating back millennia thousands of years. The Vietnam Academy of Social Sciences unearthed fossilized tea leaves and trees in Phu Tho province. Among the region’s esteemed producers is Hoai Trung Company, renowned for its “Hoai Trung Premium Dinh Tea.” This green tea is a harmony of flavor and aroma, crafted from the finest young tea buds using advanced Japanese technology. Skilled artisans, adhering to strict protocols, ensure the consistent quality that earned this tea the prestigious 5-star OCOP certification.

# Ban Co Peak: A Must-Visit Attraction in Da Nang City
5 min
[](https://vivavn.com/da-nang/)
Da Nang
[](https://youtu.be/yXRHkObK0jg?si=MtZNhUVbl0eZ9jv2)
_Ban Co Peak, or Chessboard Peak, located in Da Nang City, is a must-visit attraction. Sitting at almost 700 meters above sea level, it offers a cool and comfortable climate. Standing here, you can take in the breathtaking view of Da Nang City and the expansive blue ocean. The journey from base to peak is a delightful experience_.
Share on FacebookShare on X (Twitter)Share on PinterestShare on LinkedinShare on Email
## Key takeaways from this article
Things to know before you go
Tips for visiting Ban Co Peak
Legend of Ban Co Peak
Exciting adventures along the path to Ban Co Peak
## Things to Know Before You Go
**Location:** Ban Co Peak is situated on [**Son Tra Peninsula**](https://vivavn.com/son-tra-peninsula/), 17 kilometers from Da Nang city center.
**Getting there:** You can reach Ban Co Peak by bicycle, motorbike, car, taxi, or on foot.
**Hiking:** The hike to the top of Ban Co Peak takes about 2-3 hours, depending on your fitness level. The trail is well-maintained but can be challenging in some sections.
**Opening hours:** Ban Co Peak is open from sunrise to sunset.
**Entrance fee:** Admission to Ban Co Peak is free.
## Highlights
**Panoramic views:** From the summit, you can enjoy stunning 360-degree views of Da Nang city, the coastline, the East Sea, and the surrounding mountains.
**A statue of a pensive immortal:** The statue depicts the pensive immortal seated beside a stone chess table
**Tranquil atmosphere:** Escape the hustle and bustle of the city and immerse yourself in the serene ambiance of Ban Co Peak.
**Wildlife:** Keep an eye out for monkeys, red-shanked douc langurs, birds, and other wildlife along the trail.
## Tips for Visiting Ban Co Peak
**1. Visit on dry days:** The road to the peak is steep and can be slippery in the [**rain**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rain). Landslides are also more likely to occur during wet weather.
**2. Clear skies for city views:** If you want to enjoy panoramic views of Da Nang from the top, plan your visit for a day with minimal clouds. Hazy conditions can obscure the city view.
**3. No automatic scooters allowed:** Automatic scooters are prohibited from ascending to the peak due to past traffic accidents involving these vehicles on Son Tra Peninsula.
**4. Free admission:** Entry to Ban Co Peak is free of charge.
**5. Wear comfortable shoes:** The hike to the top can be strenuous, so wear sturdy shoes with good traction.
**6. Bring sunscreen and a hat:** The sun can be strong, especially during the midday hours.
**7. Carry plenty of water:** Stay hydrated throughout your hike by bringing enough water for the round trip.
**8. Follow park regulations:** Observe all posted signs and regulations to ensure a safe and enjoyable experience.
## Legend of Ban Co Peak
According to local folklore, ages ago, two immortal beings played chess atop Son Tra Mountain, locked in an endless stalemate. One day, while some fairy maidens frolicked and bathed at the beach below, distracting one of the immortals, he made a crucial mistake and was defeated. The victorious immortal returned to the heavens, leaving the defeated one behind to ponder his loss. Despite his efforts to find a solution, he remained stuck. In commemoration, the locals erected a stone chessboard, accompanied by a statue of the pensive immortal, naming the mountain peak Ban Co, or Chessboard Peak.
## Exciting adventures along the path to Ban Co Peak
### The journey from Son Tra base to Ban Co Peak
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
The journey from the base of Son Tra to Ban Co Peak is an adventure. The winding road up to the peak gives you a sense of thrill and excitement. As you ascend from an altitude of 400 meters, you’ll notice the impressive natural beauty of Son Tra. The mist begins to appear, creating a refreshing and pleasant climate. Along the way, you’ll be surrounded by lush primeval forests on both sides of the road.
There are designated spots where you can stop and admire the breathtaking views of Da Nang City, Tien Sa Port, and the vast expanse of the East Sea. Keep your eyes peeled because you might encounter monkeys, red-shanked douc langurs, and other wildlife along the way. It’s a journey filled with wonder and surprises, making every twist and turn a memorable experience.
Photographer: Tien Sa Port by Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
### What awaits you at Ban Co Peak?
Photographer: Huy Dope (facebook.com/huy.h.nguyen.104/)
Upon reaching Ban Co Peak, you’ll encounter a statue of an immortal deep in contemplation beside a stone chessboard. From this vantage point, two captivating scenarios await: under clear skies, behold the panoramic views of Da Nang city and the expansive East Sea; while under a cloudy sky, immerse yourself in the surreal beauty of cloudscape. It’s a place that promises an unforgettable experience.
We’d like to inform you about the reason why scooters are not allowed to go up Ban Co Peak. There have been several traffic accidents involving scooter riders attempting to reach the peak in the past. Consequently, since 2019, the Da Nang city authorities have enforced a ban on scooters for travel to Ban Co Peak

# Vietnamese Startup Creates Fashion and Decor from Areca Leaf Sheaths
We’re proud to introduce the Cau Xanh Dat Quang cooperative, where environmentally friendly products are made from areca leaf sheaths.
4 min
[](https://vivavn.com/eco-friendly-products/)
Eco-friendly products
[](https://vivavn.com/category/areca-leaf-sheath-products/)
Areca leaf
__We’re proud to introduce the Cau Xanh Dat Quang cooperative, where environmentally friendly products are made from areca leaf sheaths.__
## Introduction
In Tien Phuoc District, Quang Nam Province, Vietnam, areca trees are a vital part of life. The area is known as the “Areca Capital” of the province, and the leaves of the areca tree are traditionally used for a variety of purposes.
In 2022, a group of women from the Loc Yen commune of Tien Phuoc founded a startup called Cau Xanh Dat Quang Cooperative. They saw an opportunity to create sustainable and [eco-friendly products](https://vivavn.com/vietnam-eco-friendly-products/) from [areca leaf sheaths](https://vivavn.com/areca-leaf-sheaths/), which are often discarded as waste.
Using their skills and creativity, the women of Cau Xanh Dat Quang Cooperative produce a range of products including bags, hats, and flower pots, etc.
Through hard work and dedication, Cau Xanh Dat Quang Cooperative has achieved initial success. Their products have been well-received by consumers, and the company is now working to expand its production and reach new markets.
## Production Process of Cau Xanh Dat Quang Cooperative
**1. Areca Sheath Collection (March – August)**
  * Areca sheaths are collected from March to August each year.
  * Each areca tree sheds about 4 leaves per year.


**2. Quality Selection**
  * Only the best quality areca sheaths are selected.
  * They must be bright white, free from mold, and collected immediately after shedding.


**3. Drying**
  * The collected areca sheaths are dried in the sun to remove moisture and ensure quality.


**4. Storage**
  * The dried areca sheaths are stored in a warehouse with a dehumidifier to prevent moisture and mold during the rainy season.


**5. Soaking and Shredding**
  * The dried areca sheaths are soaked in water to soften them, then shredded.
  * The shredded areca sheaths are then dried again.


**6. Weaving**
  * The shredded areca sheaths are woven into the final product.


**7. Drying**
  * The finished product is dried in a drying room to ensure that it is completely dry and free of moisture.


**8. Application of AB Bioglue**
  * A layer of AB bioglue is applied to the product to protect it from mold and ensure durability.


**9. Final Drying**
  * The product is dried again after the application of bioglue.


**10. Storage**
  * The finished product is stored in a warehouse until it is ready to be shipped or sold to customers.
